text:
If I could give this six stars, I would.  This satisfies ALL my requirements for a "great" recipe!  Get a load of this, and I am not exaggerating:  it's quick and easy, inexpensive, attractive to look at, delicious, and very very healthy.  It travels AND refrigerates well and it can be eaten hot or cold.  What else is there to say?  I like to double the batch and bring it to work all week for lunch.  Sometimes I add chopped red bell pepper to the onion and garlic saute, but that's mostly for added color and nutrition.  It's also excellent just the way it is!  Two thumbs up!

text:
This recipe was great! I served it as a side dish, but it definitely has potential to be a main course. I used one can of black beans and chicken stock because I didn't have veggie stock on hand. Next time I'll add a drained can of tomatoes with green chiles. I let my quinoa soak while I did my prep work, a total of about 10 minutes, and the quinoa came out soft and mushy (like a wet couscous). I think you can skip the soaking part for a firmer, "al dente" quinoa and that should taste fine. I think soaking for an hour would have turned it completely into mush.

text:
This one gets five stars. We had never tried quinoa, so we weren't sure what to expect. I followed another reviewer's tip to rinse the quinoa well before cooking, and there was no bitter taste.
My changes: Added the liquid from a can of tomatoes to chicken broth to make 1-1/2 cups, added a can of Costco chicken breast, and diced a orange bell pepper I had on hand. We added grated cheddar and sour cream at the table.
The seasonings were very nice, although next time (and there WILL be a next time) I will likely add a tiny bit more cayenne pepper.
My husband really raved over this one, although he tends to be wary of new "health" foods. He was also please with how economical this recipe can be.
This is a winner!

text:
The proportions and flavors are mostly good, and I changed the directions only slightly. Two cans of black beans seemed too much to me, so I stopped at one. Make sure you rinse your quinoa if it needs it! Otherwise this might come out very bitter. Also, hold back your garlic until your onions are at least halfway done or it will burn, and throw in the quinoa shortly after. Toasting it lends amazing flavor. Then, add the spices and saute for a moment more, mixing thoroughly, before adding the broth of your choice. Otherwise a great recipe. Thank you!

text:
I'd never prepared nor eaten quinoa before (pronounced “keen-wa”; I didn't even know that!). ;) It is supposed to be very healthy & a complete protein, so I wanted to try it.  This was a spicy hot dish, but not too much for us.  I used olive oil instead of veg oil, and chicken broth rather than veg broth.  I only used one can of black beans; two would have been too much; I'd prefer that the quinoa stand out more than the beans.  We really liked this dish and I will make it again.

text:
I used bulgur wheat instead of quinoa (I'm a poor college student and the bulgur was MUCH cheaper!) but the recipe was still fantastic!!! The spices are just right! I used 1 can of black beans and 1 can of corn , and partially cooked the bulgur before adding it to the onions and garlic. The recipe seems pretty forgiving and would probably work with a variety of grains. Delicious and healthy! Will make again!

text:
Many reviewers reported the dish ended up mushy or soupy.  Quinoa is a very, very delicate grain, so I modified the recipe as follows: I cooked the quinoa, spices and broth in a separate saucepan, according to package instructions.  Meanwhile, in a large skillet, I sauted the onions, and garlic.  Then I added the beans/corn.  When onions/beans/corn were heated through, I VERY gently tossed in the cooked quinoa & cilantro, being careful not to stir too much.  Turned out great!   I hope this is helpful for other readers.

text:
Simple, healthy, adaptable, yay! This was a little bland for our tastes, so I'll be kicking up the spices a notch but I'll definitely make it again. I doubled the recipe except for the black beans and added a bell pepper, and it would have served at least 6 as a main dish. (We wanted the leftovers for lunches.) It was ok cold too. Btw the bulk grains section of our groceries here are starting to carry quinoa for $3.39/lb. Ask your grocer to carry it, I was told it was up to $8.99 at health food stores.

text:
This was surprisingly excellent.  I have made quinoa 2 times and hated it.  The flavor just turned me off.  But, my husband likes it so I thought this would be a good "compromise" recipe.  When prepping to cook, I googled "cook quinoa" and found that you need to rinse it before cooking it.  RINSE IT!  It made all the difference.  The bitterness that occurs naturally on the grain disappeared and I was able to fully enjoy the dish.  We used only one can of beans and canned corn, but I followed to rest exactly.  This was just awesome and made me feel like I was eating something very healthy and nutritious.  I have already recommended this to several coworkers.  Thanks!!

text:
delicious as is! I used fresh cilantro, cut fresh corn off cobs, and "made" the black beans from scratch (used about 1.5 cups of black beans and 3 ears of corn). At the end, after adding all the ingredients together, I kept it in the pot on very low heat to blend all the flavors together, for about 30 minutes, stirring occasionally. The sugar from the corn and the taste of the cilantro are in every bite. So good!

text:
This is a fabulous find.  I served it as a side dish for dinner, and had the leftovers as a main dish for lunch the next day. It keeps in the fridge for days and even gets better. Great texture, great flavor.  And so healthful!  I love cilantro and garlic, so I doubled the amount of both.  Fresh corn is in season, so I used fresh instead of frozen (just added it raw when corn was called for).  For color, I recommend adding some diced red pepper when you are browning the onion, or just stir it in raw at the end.  I will make this again and again. Thank you to 3LionCubs for providing this recipe!

text:
This was my first recipe attempt with Quinoa. It was a great success!!! I used this as a main dish, so I felt the two cans of black beans were definitely needed. I made a few minor changes to the recipes. I used less cumin, dried cilantro (Maybe a half tablespoon) and I ended up adding a little more broth. It seemed to be getting a little too dry. I also chopped up one roma tomato. Next time will add more tomato. This dish tasted so healthy. I loved it and so did my teenage daughter. She chose to add some grated cheese and a dollop of sour cream. She loved it that way.

I'd never even heard of quinoa, much less cooked with it, so I followed the recipe exactly.  My husband and toddler and I all loved it!  I halved the amount to avoid a bunch of left-overs if we didn't like it. I served it as a meatless main dish and it we ate it all. I thought the proportion of beans-quinoa-corn was perfect.  This is the sort of recipe you can play around with the seasonings to suit that of your family's preference.  Definitely a keeper!  Next time I'll make the whole amount so we can have leftovers since other reviewers noted that the leftovers were even better!

text:
Delicious!! Quinoa is a South American seed that is covered with a very bitter coating that protects the seeds from being eaten by birds. It is so important to rinse this coating off in a strainer with plenty of  cold running water. It can turn mushy so be gentle with it and don't mix it too long when adding the beans and cilantro. I have never soaked quinoa, as some rviewers have mentioned. So yummy and healthy, thank you:)

userID:
13760611
Display Name:
Eran del Castillo
isPro:
False
followersCount:
12
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1157114.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I am a college student on a budget and have sworn to a no-eating-out to eat cheaper and healthier. I have made this recipe three times and it's easily my new favorite dish. It only takes one pot, I can stock up on the ingredients to make it again and, for someone once hopelessly addicted to Chipotle, it satisfies my burrito bowl cravings.

I've made some changes when experimenting. First, the onions and garlic seem like a lot, but I've noticed the flavors aren't really present in the final dish so I put a little bit more and brown them in olive oil with some red pepper flakes for extra heat. I toss the quinoa with them in the hot oil to toast it (Never had to soak/rinse the quinoa), and use chicken broth and part of one of those chicken stock gels for extra poultry flavor and seasoning.

Because of the chicken stock, I don't use any salt, but double the cumin, add about 1.5 as much cayenne, and lots of pepper. I'll usually taste it at this point and expect it to taste like /too much spice/, too salty, too hot, but keep in mind that these spices will disperse to cover the beans and corn. In spite of the reviews, I like the amount of beans and add both cans.

I have served this recipe with avocado slices, shredded cheddar, and a fried egg on top for a huevos rancheros-type dinner, and with chipotle marinated chicken or slices of steak on top for extra protein. My boyfriend who only seems to eat junk food LOVES this recipe, and that itself is a miracle.

I just made this exactly as the recipe reads (well, I used dried cilantro instead of fresh because I don't use a lot of fresh herbs, therefore they go to waste).  It is wonderful...fantastic! My husband loves it too! It is quite spicy, so if you are sensitive to spicy things like I am, you may want to halve the cayenne. Who knew 1/4 tsp. would do that?! Well, probably a lot of you ;o) I also only used one can of black beans only because I didn't read the recipe correctly and only had one can. I must say, though that an extra can would have made this more like "black beans with a little quinoa," you don't need more than one can.

text:
This was my first time cooking quinoa and I am officially hooked!! This meal was so delicious and full of flavour.(I'm Jamaican, so bland food is a big no no)I read through some of the other reviews and made some of the suggested changes such as: 1) I soaked the quinoa for 20 min. then rinsed before cooking. 2) I used chicken broth instead of veggi broth. 3) I used 1 tin of black beans and it was the perfect amount, I think 2 tins would have overpowered the quinoa. 4) I did not use as much cayenne pepper because my daughter is not a pepper fan, I used about 1/4 the amount and it gave a nice hint of flavour. 

Give this recipe a try and your taste buds will thank you later!

text:
I've made this several times now, and each time I think it gets better. Originally I found it to be a little bland (I double the spices and the corn), but I've discovered a couple tricks: do not be shy with the salt, and a fresh squeeze of lemon/lime before serving goes a long way to brighten it up. Little wedges of cherry tomatoes are also a great way to add flavor.   I eat it as a main course with sweet potato fries, as a side, on spinach leaves as a salad base, in tacos, in burritos, with a fried egg and tomatoes - hot or cold, it's really great for it's flexibility.

text:
SIMPLE AND DELICIOUS- Like others, I used dry beans, (12 minutes in the pressure cooker to avoid canned, I'm there!) and I did use fresh corn off the cob as well. Instead of the cayenne, I finely chopped a green and red jalapeno. I had to put the remainder in the freezer immediately to keep from EATING IT ALL!!! GREAT RECIPE!

text:
I tried this recipe because I was looking for a way to cook quinoa for the first time. From the moment I tasted it I knew it would become a regular. It is amazingly comforting and exciting at the same time. The only really fresh ingredient is cilantro, so it's easy to always keep the ingredients on hand. My husband and I always eat it as a nutritious main dish...and the recipe, for us, only makes 2 servings. So usually I double it (but I don't double the black beans) and we eat it for lunch the next day. It is as good or BETTER at room temperature the next day. I toast the rinsed quinoa in a hot dry pan  before I use it and I double the cayanne. I LOVE THIS RECIPE! TRY IT! I tell all my friends about it and my coworkers drool when I bring it for lunch.

text:
Wow!!!!!  I've never tried quinoa and I was kind of skeptical.  I mean "healthy" often equals anywhere from bland to downright gross in my book.  But, in an effort to cut back on all the junk food this world has to offer and to eat more healthy food, I've searched the internet for tasty foods that are also good for me.  This recipe easily fills both categories for me!  YUM!!!  I stuck to the original recipe other than toasting the quinoa first and using low sodium chicken broth instead of veg. broth (it's what I had in the house).  The spices gave it just the right amount of kick.  I highly recommend this recipe!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
LOVE THIS!! I don't follow recipes exactly and, aside from the quinoa, I don't measure much. I sauteed diced green onions, 1/2 each red & green bellpeppers, and fresh garlic in olive oil. Added pepper, chili powder, cayenne pepper, onion powder, and garlic powder (mmm garlic) then toasted the rinsed quinoa. I added a can of low sodium diced tomatos *undrained* and a can of diced green chiles then some sliced black olives. One cup of "no chicken" broth and about 1/2 cup water. I put in a mixed can of kidney/pinto/black beans because it sounded good, normally black beans would be great. One thing I haven't seen on reviews is adding a bit of nutritional yeast (1/4-1/2 cup). It makes it a little creamy and cheesy. So good. Eat with tortilla chips or as taco/burrito filling.

text:
Like some of the other reviewers I have a fiancé who is a little skeptical of healthy dishes and he licked his plate clean! (So did I!) i cannot believe how tasty this was and I even turned it into a main dish by cleaning out my cabinet.  I added 1 breast of chicken I had on hand (diced it and sautéed w the onion, marinated w some crushed red pepper flakes, garlic and pepper for a few hours prior), cut the recipe in half, used chicken broth instead of veggie, EVOO instead of veg oil, more than doubled cayenne pepper ( we love things very spicy), and use freeze dried cilantro bc that's what I had on hand.  Toyed with the idea of adding a can of garbanzo beans but decided to try it without for the first time.  May add them next time just to add some extra protein and bc I love them!  Will def make the full amount next time and keep the leftovers for lunches the next day.  5 servings turned out to be 2 and between the crushed red pepper and all the cayenne, it was super spicy! Can't wait to make this again and again! Thanks so much for a recipe I can feel so good about!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent dish-- I eat as a main course but could easily be a side dish. When making it as a main course I use 1 can of beans and add in zucchini to save on calories. I also up the cumin to a tablespoon because I love that spice. Fresh cilantro is best, but I've used dried and it was still good. 

If you are new to cooking with quinoa, simmer means turn it way down to low. The first time I made this I left the burner on medium heat and the liquid evaporated before the quinoa was cooked- an easy fix, just add more vegetable broth. You will know it's cooked when the quinoa looks more flat and disc shaped than small and round.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This was the first time making quinoa and I have to say this recipe is AWESOME!!!  LOVE!  LOVE! LOVE! LOVE! LOVE!  The proportions and flavors are great, and I only changed the directions slightly. I used one can of organic black beans (Publix brand), added the zest and juice of one lemon, half a can of gluten free diced spicy red peppers by Hunt's, and a couple of dashes of Sazon Completa. Make sure you rinse your quinoa!!!! Otherwise this might come out very bitter. I actually soaked my quinoa for about 10 mins (the length of time it took me to chop up the onions and garlic and sautee them). Also, hold back your garlic until your onions are at least halfway done or it will burn, and throw in the quinoa shortly after. Toasting it lends amazing flavor. Otherwise, I followed the recipe to a T. Enjoy!!! I hope you love it as much as I do! =)

text:
Very, very good.  Just a note, you never have to soak Quinoa...and the recipe doesn't call for it.  It becomes like mush if you soak it; rinsing it off (if you buy in bulk it hasn't been rinsed) gets rid of any bitter taste.  Some prepackaged quinoa has already been rinsed.
Review:

The whole family loved this.  Even my very, very picky daughte!  I halved the black beans and used chicken broth.  I also added red pepper and green pepper for added color/nutrition. I cut an avocado in half and removed the pit, and spooned the quinoa into the avocado.  It looked amazing and tasted delicious with the bites of avocado.  I made it last night and I'm making a huge batch tonight and adding tofu.  We can eat it for lunch throughout the week!  Delicious.  OH - I also used frozen cilantro cubes which worked fab.

Update 7/23/2012
I made this again and used water instead of broth.  I also used 1/4 cup parsley instead of cilantro (not a big fan).  It was still really good!  I think next time I'll add a tablespoon of butter at the end just to make it a little bit creamier.
May 28,2012 I really enjoyed this dish!  I used a yellow pepper instead of cilantro and enjoyed the sweetness it added.  I used vegetable broth and can see how chicken broth would add to the flavor as well.  This is certainly a dish you could add more veggies to and make it even better.

text:
Had an unexpected southwestern flavor to it. Surprising but very good. Instead of chopping the onion, I added onion chunks and the garlic to chicken broth and pureed in the magic bullet; separated the solids from the broth and cooked according to directions. At the end, I found my quinoa still too firm so I added more chicken broth at the end and simmered until tender. Only used half the black beans recommended and added chopped sauteed mushrooms.  Delicious. Husband really liked it.

I intend to also make it a regular item around the house now since it's so good in every way possible for you!!! A million thanks to the person who submitted this recipe!!! This is my second time making quinoa (my first didn't turn out too well because it was tasteless) and this recipe has got me hooked on this power grain probably for life now! Thank you!

WOW!  Where's the six-star rating?! I had this for the first time at a friend's house.  Her 17 year old son had made it for dinner - he added some cranberries along with the black beans and cilantro,  and sprinkled it with feta before serving.  He sent us the allrecipes.com link for this recipe because after trying different versions of this, he said he liked this one the best.  I made it last night to accompany our tacos, but it can also easily stand alone.  This would be a perfect pot-luck side, and is easy to take to work for a quick lunch that doesn't need to be reheated in the office microwave.  Plenty of protein helps satisfy hunger and keeps you feeling full without all the calories, it's gluten free, and it's easy to experiment with in order to add your own flavors and style.  It's rare that such a healthy dish makes such an impression.  Go for it.  You won't be sorry!

text:
This recipe makes it easy for my kids and I to eat vegan!  I have made this over 20 times and it is perfect just as it is written, although I do usually double the amount of cumin and add 2 teaspoons of curry powder.  I have also made all types of substitutions based on what I have on hand. Rather than corn I have used peas and carrots.  I also have used edamame rather than corn.  If I want a little less sodium I have replaced half of the vegetable broth with water. At times I also use one can of black beans rather than two.  It is very difficult to mess up this delicious recipe!  It tastes great warm or cold.  P.S. To rinse off the bitter taste of the quinoa, do not forget to soak the quinoa in water for a few minutes before you begin.

text:
This was my first experience with Quinoa. I was very hesitant to it because of the mixed reviews I was getting. This recipe was so amazing that it was directly put in my recipe book and will stay there forever. I made a few tweaks to the recipe. I added only one can of black beans and added more spices (but i love spicy food.) I also used just plain water and added in an extra 1/4 cup. You dont have to use vegetable both water works just as nice and is free. I also just added a whole can of corn instead of just a cup. I also added one cup of quinoa and two cups of water. This recipe is so good and i made pork shanks with it they complimented each other very well.

userID:
12297772
Display Name:
Diane Sessler
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7115045.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My 10 year old daughter asked me to PLEASE give this dish a 5 star review. I agree, so here it is! I took the advise of other reviewers and added just one can of black beans, which was perfect for us. One reviewer said she used paprika instead of cayenne so her young child would eat it. I added both, and loved the addition of paprika! I probably used a 1/2 tsp, maybe a bit more. I also took the advise of other reviewers who waited to add the garlic until about 1/2 way through cooking the onion. I also added the quinoa to toast a bit before adding the spices, then finally, the liquid. Yummy toasty flavors developed this way. I baked 3 chicken breasts in balsamic vinaigrette (Costco Kirkland brand) for 30 minutes while I prepared the quinoa dish. I cut up the chicken into bit size pieces, and lightly tossed it into the quinoa dish. I served it in bowls and topped with grated cheddar cheese, sour cream and salsa. Easy dish! done in 40 minutes tops!

Next time I would add sliced avocado as a garnish per my daughters request. Honestly, there are so many great ways you could vary this dish. 

Thank you so much for sharing this economical, easy and tasty recipe! That meets all of my criteria for the perfect dinner! We had no left overs, but I think the dish would be great for lunch the next day.

text:
WOW!!!  I did modify the recipe a bit...  I'm a fan of quinoa, so I upped the amount to 1 cup.  Used red onion and chicken stock (in place of white onion and veg stock) and olive oil in place of veg oil.  With the increase in quinoa, I increased the liquid to 2 cups, having to add a little more while simmering.  I added a little fresh chopped broccoli with the corn, used chopped spinach in place of the cilantro and only used one can of black beans.  I also added a pinch of Kurbiskonig ("Spice Mix Pumpkin King") from Herbaria in addition to the other spices.  This recipe is so versatile.  AWESOME!

Made the receipe again...  ...this time I added some amaranth to the quinoa.  ...turned out great.

text:
After being diagnosed with diabetes I was worried I'd be doomed to a life of awful, tasteless food.  I started playing around with various grains and also thought I'd give Quinoa a try.  At first I wasn't crazy about it by itself.  But then I came across this recipe and my life was changed forever!  I had 20+ over for Mother's Day to eat.  I made just a single recipe thinking I'd be the only one eating it.  Boy, was I wrong.  The bowl was empty in no time.
I've since learned to embrace Quinoa and now love it's versatility.  I've even used it in place of rice in a rice pudding recipe!

userID:
8518739
Display Name:
diane wallach
isPro:

followersCount:
0

3

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674158.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
WOW!!!! This recipe is amazing! Even my boyfriend loved it! I did make a few changes - I used red quinoa, only one can of beans (rinsed to get rid of the sodium), no corn (all starch, no nutrition), and no sodium chicken broth. I added some chopped orange mini bell peppers to the onion, sautéed, added the garlic, sautéed a little more, added the seasonings ( a tiny extra cayenne and only a tiny sprinkle of salt, some black pepper, and the amount of cumin called for). I stirred with the seasoning, added the quinoa and cooked a little more, then added the beans and the chicken broth. I prefer the beans cooked more rather than added at the end, but they absorbed some of the liquid so I had to add some more broth for the quinoa to cook enough, but in the end, I had an AMAZING dish! I served it with skinless boneless chicken breasts that had marinated in olive oil, balsamic vinegar, and basil, and then cooked it in a sauté pan with no added oil. The balsamic kind of burned and blackened the chicken and it was delicious!
Review:

*Really good*, especially considering the simplicity of the recipe. text:
I know people get annoyed when you review a recipe that you changed but sometimes you either don't have all the ingredients or have to make changes depending on dietary needs/preferences. 

Anyway, I followed the recipe for the most part. I didn't have veggie broth so used a half cup of salsa (as another reviewer suggested) and still the full amount of water. When I added the quinoa to the onions, I did saute them for a few minutes before adding the salsa and water. The only other modification was that instead of 2 cans of blackbeans, I did one of blackbeans and 1 can red kidney beans. Very tasty recipe and you HAVE to use fresh cilantro. It adds so much flavor. Thanks so much for the super healthy and tasty recipe.

This was very good, our first time of eating quinoa. I left out the cilantro as some of us don't like that and also left the corn on the side to add individually. I used chicken broth in place of the vegetable broth and only added 1 can of beans. It was really good and will serve again. Do not add the salt if you're using chicken broth, makes it slightly too salty.

text:
This was good. I'd never made it before, but I'll make it again for sure.   I doubled the recipe but not the beans, like someone else mentioned. I didn't use the cumin, but I did add red pepper flakes which gave it a nice spicy kick. I found it too salty with the broth (I used chicken since that's what I had) and adding salt, and I didn't add much either. I think next time I'm going to use 3/4 of the broth and 1/4 water to tone that down. I think that I'm going to add tomatoes next time as well.  My 5 and 7 year old kids like this a lot as well. We served it with broiled cod and salad. Yum.

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674139.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Used this as a filling for stuffed bell peppers.  It was the perfect amount for four medium-sized peppers.  Followed instructions exactly, except only used 1 can of black beans and did not use cilantro.  For the peppers, I cut the tops off, removed the seeds and ribs, and then parboiled in lightly salted water for about 5 minutes.  I then drained them on paper towels while I finished off the quinoa filling.  When the filling was finished, I distributed among the peppers, placed in a baking dish, and popped in a preheated 400-degree oven for 20 minutes.  I then sprinkled each with about a tablespoon of finely shredded parmesan cheese, increased oven temperature to broil, and returned to the oven for just a few minutes to melt and brown the cheese.  They were absolutely delicious.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was our first time trying quinoa and we loved it. My husband was very impressed with this dish. I made the recipe exactly as written except that I used dried black beans cooked with chicken broth instead of canned beans. This recipe is a very healthy, one-pot vegan meal, but I chose to add a simple quesadilla (made with whole wheat tortillas, monterey jack and cheddar cheeses, and some leftover grilled chicken) and some steamed broccoli to round out the meal. No more Spanish Rice for me: from now on, I'll be making this recipe to complement any Mexican style meal or as a meal in itself. One warning: the cilantro flavor was strong. I love cilantro, but it is a flavor that some people don't care for. If you prefer, you may want to reduce the cilantro. I'm looking forward to trying other ways to cook quinoa, but this recipe will be hard to beat!

Very good side dish for BBQ and mexican dishes.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've now taken it to 3 parties and had numerous recipe requests.  I did make a few small changes.  I sauteed the onion and garlic in a small amount of butter, as I think onions in butter are the best.  The biggest change I made was using turkey broth in place of veggie broth.  I save juices from all meat cooked for use in gravies, roux, and other sauces.  Since quinoa particularly marries flavors of what it's cooked in, this change was key in turning it into a stellar dish.  I also used only one can of beans.  I have been using Ancient Harvest brand Inca Red Quinoa because I thought it looked more attractive than the white.  We have served this with both chicken and steak and also used it as a filling in burritos and it is excellent that way too.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I make this all the time.  It is the best quinoa (keen-wah) dish out there.  I have made it as the recipe calls and it is great.  I have made it tons of other ways and it's still great. I just add what veggies I have on hand.  My favorite way is to add chopped bell pepper with the onions and top with fresh chopped tomatoes, sour cream and shredded cheese. Salsa also gives it a kick even if you don't have cilantro on hand.  I DO Not soak the quinoa.  My husband likes this rolled into a tortilla for burritos(you could mash part of your black beans before adding them to make it thicker for wrapping up).  If you have time to toast the qunioa (until it starts to pop) in a dry skillet, it adds to the flavor.  Don't forget that quinoa is a complete protien and the beans and corn mix to make a complete protien for non-meat eaters.  This makes a great main meal as well as side dish.

This was so easy and it tastes sooo good!
I followed the recipe as is except reducing to one can of black beans and omitting the cilantro (because I hate cilantro).

This is going to be a great base recipe for tweaking to your own taste. We added crumbled feta cheese to it afterwards and it was very complimentary.

DELICIOUS either hot or cold.  Changes I made: 1 tsp. olive oil instead of veg. oil.  I substituted 1 c. bulgur grain which I poured 1c. boiling water over & let sit until water was absorbed. We love making this recipe! It was my first time making quinoa and the first time didn't work out for me. I wasn't watching the quinoa and it burned to the bottom, I only had to cook it for about 15 minutes before it was good. After making it a few times, I have doubled the cayenne pepper to make it a little hotter and now we have it weekly! It is wonderful to make ahead of time and keep in the fridge. It microwaves great! I like 2 cans of black beans, it didn't seem like too much for me.

text:
This recipe is great and very versatile. I have made this about 3 times and each time I did a little something different. One time I put it in tortillas with chicken and sliced avocados and it was really good. Last time I put it in some light flat wraps to make it a little healthier and also added chicken, sour cream and salsa. Like other reviewers, I like to just use 1 can of black beans. I also use low sodium chicken broth instead of vegetable broth. All of my friends who have tried this have liked it. It's super easy to make and I feel good about eating it since it's so healthy.

text:
Mmmmm mm! This one surprised me... totally delicious! I ate it as a side dish with steamed salmon, but it could have stood alone as its own dish. I changed a couple of small things out of what I had on hand... I didn't use frozen corn (didn't have any) and added a can of rotel... the entire two cans of black beans was a TOUCH too much for me, so I added a can and a half. I also used chicken broth instead of vegetable broth because that's what I had in the pantry. OH and I used two shallots instead of one onion. I absolutely loved it and plan on making it frequently when I need a quick healthy meal. Thanks for sharing!

text:
Made this dish today and was very pleasantly pleased with the end result!  Paired it with the Mexican pot roast that I made for shredded beef tacos and burritos. The whole family liked it...coming from the kids that is a compliment as they were introduced to quinoa before and did not like it all!!! Some of us chose to eat it as is; some had in in their beef buritos; some topped it with homemade salsa and avocados. It was yummy either way and I am sure there will be many other ways to serve this dish in the future! I followed the recipe with the excepion of using only one can of black beans  (two would  be overkill in my opionion).  We liked the flavor overall but next time I will add a teaspoon of homemade taco seasoning and a little less cayenne to broaden the flavors a little more. Maybe even try adding some peppers for color and some salsa or tomatoes in the cooking process for an added level of flavor.  An easy recipe to add some variety to it!

text:
First Quinoa recipe and my family loved it! I made a few changes:
1)Used Olive Oil
2)Added 1/2 teaspoon ground coriander
3)Added 1/4 teaspoon turmeric
4)Added 1/4 teaspoon red pepper seed
5)Cooked all spices/herbs with the onions & garlic
5)Used 1 1/4 cup chicken stock
6)Used 1/2 teaspoon salt
7)Used 1 teaspoon white pepper
8)Only used 1 can of well rinsed & drained black beans
9)Used 2 Tablespoons dried cilantro - I had used all of my fresh:(
I cooked it an additional 5 minutes before adding the corn. I served it with homemade turkey burgers for a nice healthy dinner!

I thought this was excellent with 2 cans of beans, I don't really understand what people are saying about it being over-kill. I felt the amount of quinoa and beans were balanced very nicely. I would say to buy 2 cans and if you find it's enough, save the next can for next time, but you don't want to be disappointed with it being under-beaned. If I could make any suggestions, it's fantastic with avocado and chopped red bell pepper. 10 oz of this stuff was only 200 calories, it's extraordinarily low-cal and it's delicious.

Wow! A 10 not a five. Amazing flavor packed in so few ingredients. Skip the rice & beans - eat this:) I lacked onion and cilantro so was forced to use onion powder and a squeeze of lime. text:
This is s.e.r.i.o.u.s.l.y. amazing! I tried it after reading many of the glowing reviews (of which I was highly skeptical). But it is very easy to prepare and the results are incredible. Please try this, you won't be sorry. Don't leave out a thing! I almost left out the corn, thinking it wouldn't be missed. Instead I ran to the store and grabbed a bag of frozen kernels. The corn imparts a delicate sweetness and a little pop when you bite into it. I love to eat this dish with a heaping dollop of plain greek style yogurt, green onions, cilantro and bit of finely minced hot pepper (a red one is especially pretty) Thank you thank you thank you for sharing this fabulous recipe.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my new favorite dish!! With a few tweaks...with all the disgusting things about meat in the news right now, I was looking for a vegetarian dish I could turn to a couple times a week..this is it..

First, I eat like a child in that I don't care for chunks of veggies...so, I blended up a can of rotel adding enough water to make 1 1/2 cups. I added that to my rinsed quinoa along with salt, pepper, onion powder, garlic powder, cayenne pepper, cumin, chili powder, and a few sprinkles of chipotle tobasco pepper sauce...I brought it to a boil, turned the heat down and simmered 25 minutes..then I added a drained can of mexicorn and drained/rinsed black beans...I topped it with a little cheese and sour cream...perfection!!!

text:
Prepared recipe as written, but scaled down to 2 servings...required additional broth (used regular vegetable broth because didn't have the low-sodium variety). Broth amount per recipe evaporated and the quinoa mixture nearly burned before I caught and added enough additional broth to have a moist mixture. Also, added 1/2 seeded and de-veined habanero pepper. With these revisions, the recipe was really good with just the right amount of heat for my taste.

text:
This was my first time ever making quinoa so I was a bit leary plus my husband had had it in the past and hated the texture of it but I decided to try this recipe anyway and we both loved it! It's a great recipe for newbies to quinoa. I did have to cook mine a bit longer til it was transculent and did add a bit of water to get it there (could be because of my altititude) I also left out the cilantro cuz I didn't have any on hand and didn't feel like I was missing it and I only used 1 can of black beans and 3/4 c of corn. I think the full amounts would've been overkill. I also used extra virgin olive oil vs vegetable oil. Definitely will make this a regular side dish in my menus plus the health benefits of quinoa are an added bonus!

text:
A great recipe that can be served up either cold or hot.  I doubled the recipe, adding 2 cans garbanzo beans, 2 cans black beans, 1 red pepper (diced), 2 bags frozen white sweet corn, juice of fresh limes, olive oil, etc.  I first cooked the quinoa in vegetable broth for the liquid, let it cool, then combined it with the other ingredients.  I mixed the olive oil, spices and lime juice together and tossed with the quinoa and veggies.  Very quick, healthy, and tasty!  I plan on making this regularly because it is so healthy.

region:

country:

text:
As others have noted, this is the perfect recipe, especially for a broke 20-something cooking for one. First and foremost, it's absolutely delicious hot or cold. It refrigerates well, which is a plus (for lunches during the week). Also, it's super cheap (especially if you make smart substitutions, like vegetable bouillon for vegetable stock and chopped garlic from a jar instead of fresh garlic. But definitely spring for the fresh cilantro--that's essential). It's also really good for you, with great protein from the quinoa and beans, and it looks gorgeous. I have been raving about this recipe to my friends, and I'm sure you will, too. Enjoy!

Very good recipe for quinoa! I served this with Beef fajitas and the family loved it! I rinsed the quinoa, didn't soak, and it turned out fine - not bitter, and not too mushy like some posts mentioned.  I added some of the extras mentioned and it was delish - green pepper, diced tomatoes with green chilies(drained), and some taco seasoning to give it a little more kick...felt the heat factor would be fine to start off with re: cayenne pepper. I doubled the batch, but only added the two cans called for in the original recipe.  Will definitely make this again and could totally see this as a stand alone meal! Thank you Allrecipes!

text:
This recipe is awesome. Prepared as is, it's a great core and is really tasty. However, the second time, I added a can of no-sodium-added diced tomatoes and it made it even better.

The third time, I added the can of tomatoes and also entire bunch of spinach. I chopped the bunch coarsely and steamed it for about 5-7 minutes while the mixture was cooking in the pot and I added the wilted spinach at the same time as the cilantro and stirred it around. It's excellent and super-nutritious.

This is AWESOME!! I would give this more stars if I could!!  As a new vegetarian, I am always looking for new recipes and feel like I have found a winner in this one!  I made a couple of changes based on what I had on hand in my cabinets - 1 can of black beans and 1 can of pintos, 1/2 of a low-sodium taco seasoning packet, and added some Ro-Tel that was open and needed to be used.  I put a little fat free shredded cheddar and sour cream in it just before I ate it - AMAZING AND SO EASY TO MAKE!  Thank you so much for this recipe; I will be making this MANY more times!

I had never had Quinoa before but I had been wanting to try it for some time. I am VERY pleased that I found this recipe! It was DELICIOUS!! Here at our house we are trying to lower our cholesterol so this was a perfect substitution for meat as a main course. text:
As written, this recipe gets four stars for taste, health, ease, and overall appeal.  However, with the addition of a little cheese (I tried Monterey Jack), fresh diced tomatoes, canned green chiles, and by using fresh corn cut off the cob, this recipe skyrocketed to 5+.  The quality of ingredients has such a huge impact on this recipe - use fresh ingredients if at all possible - fresh garlic, onion, etc.  Home cooked black beans would be even better - kicking the "canned" taste while reducing the sodium.  Thanks for a really great recipe that I'll surely repeat.

I've found this recipe to be forgivable and adaptable - you can add any enhancements you want.

It is my new favorite recipe, yeah, it is that good!

I made this early last week and have been thinking about this dish everyday since.  I cut in half, soaked the quinoa for 20 minutes or so.  I used about 1/2 the cumin and toasted it with the quinoa as it sauteed.  I love cumin, but not everyone does.  A smaller dose is just enough to add a delicious flavor, and no one has any idea that the flavor is cumin.  Added the corn and beans at the same time - cooked the whole dish about 10 less then suggested.  Also subbed parsley for the cilantro - love cilantro but was using what I had on hand.

An excellent recipe as is and that's also very adaptable. At various times I've added chopped winter squash, extra veggies (whatever was on hand), and used this as the filling for a tortilla wrap or a hollowed-out zucchini or acorn squash. Always terrific. 

I do usually add more cayenne or a chopped fresh chili pepper, because we like things a bit of the hot side. Frying a crumbled hot Italian sausage and adding it to the mix is a good addition for the carnivores in the family.

text:
I love this recipe. I've made it a lot of times, and vary it somewhat each time. I've enjoyed it no matter how it has been made.

Some modifications I've made on different occasions: 
Chicken Broth instead of Vegetable Broth or half of each.
Added Water Chestnuts, and red and yellow peppers right at the end.
Canned corn instead of frozen
1 can of black beans instead of two (in fact I've doubled all the other ingredients and still only used 1/2 the black beans)
a splash of soy sauce (note: i've only done this on the occasions where i've used primarily veggie broth and not chicken broth)

I once even used 1/3 couscous when i ran out of quinoa.
No matter how you change this recipe you can't mess it up.
healthful, and delicious every time.

This was my first time making quinoa, and I'll definitely be making it again.  Even my carnivorous husband loved it, although he wanted a bit of cheese on top.  I'm amazed at how quick, easy, and tasty this was!

--I did add some diced tomatoes which I highly recommend both for flavor and attractive color. (Only use one can of beans! That's perfect!)
--I did not do any special preparation to the quinoa.  I was afraid it would be slightly crunchy or nutty, like brown rice can be, but found it to be soft and pleasingly palatable instead.

text:
oh yum. this was just GOOD. not too difficult either. just chopped the garlic a red onion and a red pepper, threw it in a pot while i rinsed the quinoa and chopped the cilantro, and 20 minutes later - yum! doesn't get much easier. It could be a bit spicier I think, but the flavors are really nice. I added the squeeze of lime, which always compliments cilantro so well. i used both cans of beans and didn't think they overpowered it at all (plus, for vegans, it's an extra dose of protein!). served it in south beach whole wheat wraps, with a side of veggies (baked vegetables I on this site) - an excellent vegan meal, filling and tasty. i plan to add sliced avocado for a little "good fat" too. i already ate it as leftovers, cold, for lunch and it was great. it would be delish on a bed of greens, with maybe a bit of salsa or pico de gallo. I'll definitely make it again; it will likely become a lunch-for-the-week staple!

I give this five stars both for its flavor and nutrition content.  I had never tried quinoa before, and this was a great recipe for trying something new.  I would probably add a little more cayenne pepper to taste, but I like things spicy!  I would also probably use the whole can of vegetable broth, since the beans could use a little more moisture.  This dish seems to be best eaten right after you fix it, since the cilantro is still fresh and flavorful, but it also works well for lunch the next day.

This was very good and very different. I served this to a group including my mom, who can not eat corn. I substituted diced red bell pepper for color and some sweetness. It was a hit. We did not find it too beany for our tastes, but our family is big on the black beans. I will definitely make this again.

This was my first time cooking with quinoa.  Mine turned out pretty mushy and soupy.  It could be the pot I used, it doesnt cook rice well either.  This dish was just ok to me, I added a bunch of salsa (Sarah's salsa) and it tastes better.  I'm wonering if I'd like it better if I cooked the quinoa separate, then added the ingredients.  I think it would be good with green onions and red peppers, black beans, corn and garlic...that would be my preference.  ETA:  so its a couple years later and I've finally learned how to quick quinoa correctly.  I will have to give this recipe a try again, I've learned to watch the quinoa as it may cook quicker and then I can dump out the extra liquid if need be.  I bet this recipe is good done correctly.

This was my first attempt at quinoa and it was a hit.  Two of my 3 kids loved it, the 3rd is only 2, so her opinion doesn't count, LOL.  My husband liked it, mother in law loved it and as far as I know, my father in law liked it as well.

I ended up having to cook it an additional 10 minutes, which is no biggie.  I also omitted the cilantro  mainly cause I forget but the people in my family aren't crazy about it anyway.

text:
Yummy.  Here were my changes:  Chix broth instead of veg. broth cuz that's what I had on hand; I added one coursely chopped carrot about half-way into the cooking time for the quinoa (for color and crunch!); added only one can of black beans (I felt that was plenty); added one can of diced tomatoes w/roasted garlic; and used dried cilantro instead of fresh, and threw in a couple of dashes of "Mexican" seasoning along with the cumin.  This is a good dish, and one in which you can try lots of different variations on.  The quinoa itself is a very soft, light grain.  I'm glad I tried it!  Thx for the recipe!

text:
This is hearty and flavorful and healthy.  I added a chopped red pepper and served with diced avocado as someone suggested. I used this as a meatless entree.  I cook quinoa separately - I find it gets sticky when I cook it with anything else.  Be sure to rinse thoroughly.  I "toast" it until it's dry before adding water, then simmer 20 min.  I sauteed the onion and garlic and then added the spices and sauteed 2 minutes before adding the chopped pepper to saute a little longer.  I added the corn and beans and heated through.  Then I stirred in the quinoa and cilantro.  We'll make this again.

HGelo

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4543222.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been cooking this dish for 6 or 7 years now, and it's a constant favorite in our house. Pleases vegetarians/vegans and omnivores alike, and everyone who "doesn't like quinoa" gobbles it down after they try it. Every time I make it, I say aloud, "Why don't I make this more often?!" because it's just that yummy.

I make this as either a starchy side dish to accompany grilled meat/fish, as part of a Taco Tuesday spread, or to bring as a potluck dish. It's a great alternative to salad for vegetarians, as well as safe for those who are gluten free (we have several of those in our family, and I always bring food they can eat to potlucks).

My tips: 
*Always rinse your quinoa well, even if the bag says it's been washed; this helps eliminate the bitter taste that can accompany this grain
*1 can of black beans is enough; 2 cans felt unbalanced 
*Use fresh or (defrosted) frozen corn; canned does not provide the same crisp texture that this dish needs to keep it from having a mushy mouth-feel

Display Name:
Mary Anne

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674151.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this but changed it a bit to make a main meal out of it. I used chicken breast, and cut them into 1 inch or so cubes. Then sautéed them in oil. Then I set them aside. Then I pealed and diced one sweat potato. I combined the spices and oil and poured that on the sweet potato in a bowl. Using a foil lined cookie sheet, I spread the seasoned sweet potato on the cookie sheet and baked at 350 degrees for 30 minutes. While the sweet potato was cooking I continued with the recipe.  I used one can drained and rinse black beans and one can drained pinto beans. I added the cooked chicken to the main recipe and cooked as directed. When almost done, I removed the sweet potato and added it to the pan. It was very good. I did use more broth by maybe a 1/2 cup. This recipe makes a lot of food. Can easily feed a family of 6.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was delicious!  I took the advice of one reviewer and added cheddar cheese and sour cream.  I had to use extra chicken broth (substituted for vegetable broth) and some water to keep the quinoa from burning.  The next time I make this, I will definitely add some green peppers, can of tomatoes with green chiles, zucchini, fresh lemon juice, and maybe mix it up with other vegetables after each iteration.

Also, I liked one of the suggestions from another reviewer: hold back your garlic until your onions are at least halfway done or it will burn, and throw in the quinoa shortly after. Toasting it lends amazing flavor. Then, add the spices and saute for a moment more, mixing thoroughly, before adding the broth of your choice

text:
Very nice recipe. I like to take bean salads for lunch during the week, and this one doesn't disappoint. Like others, I substituted chicken broth for vegetable broth. I also threw in leftover shredded carrot, chopped celery, half a red bell pepper, some fresh salsa and a chopped fresh jalapeño. Will make again! Thanks for the recipe. Update: I made this again, but cooked the quinoa separately. Then the whole dish came out bland. I added carrots and jalapeños, along with some diced tomatoes and extra cumin. Still fell flat. Too dry. Too bland. Then I added some chipotle mayo. That did the trick. A bit more spicy, but sure ramped up the flavour and texture. Very tasty!

text:
Delicious!  Main-dish complete proteins and gluten-free!  I had started the quinoa in another pan before I knew what to serve with it, so it certainly came out a little different - I used a can of Mexican style corn with jalapenos in it.  I used only one can of black beans.  We love black beans but my 9" skillet would have overflowed with another can.  I used V8 for the vegetable broth (just added it in last to moisten the dish up) and substituted chipotl for the cayenne.  I added about 5 mushrooms, sliced with the onion and garlic, just because we love them.  Served with a sprinkle of shredded mixed cheeses, half an avocado (diced) and a tablespoonful of sour cream.  Colorful and wonderful.  It was only with great self-control that I did not run to finish up the leftovers in the pan when I finished before my son.

text:
Did this and loved it! Changed some things to make it like a chili: 
Used black quinoa, fresh corn, and black beans. 6 cloves of garlic (fried in coconut oil at the beginning), and a bunch of spices: red pepper flakes, black pepper, parsley, bay powder, pizza seasoning, cumin and oregano. Also used real chicken broth (frozen from another meal). 
Next time l'll do the quinoa on the side, the beans on the side, and just fold everything together, and let it simmer for a bit... onions ended up too mushy for my taste. 
but otherwise, it was amazing!

text:
This is a great recipe. I gave it 4 stars because my family found it much too spicy (and I already didn't use quite as much Cayenne as called for) and I only used 1 can of black beans and think 2 would have been too much. I will be making this again for sure, but I will try with just a pinch of Cayenne next time instead of the not-quite-1/4 tsp that I used this time. As is, it tasted pretty good with some plain yogurt mixed in to cut the heat, but we couldn't eat it without.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5539519.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made as directed except I did not have broth so I used 1 1/2  cup water with 2 bouillon cubes dissolved.  When I first taste tested the quinoa for doneness, I was worried because it was extremely salty!! That's something you can't fix! I proceeded on with the recipe, and had to add a little more water as the quinoa was not as tender as I'd have liked.  Once all the ingredients were added and simmered, it tasted fine, however, if I need to make that substitution again, I would only use 1 bouillon cube!  Also, it makes alot, I reheated some in the microwave 2 nights later to go with our dinner, and it tasted even better!  One of those dishes that gets better after it sits a day or so!  Will definitely make again!

text:
Love this recipe with a few adjustments. I use chicken broth instead of veg. broth. Reduce black beans to 1 can. Reduce corn to 1/2 cup. Increase cumin to 2 tsp. and reduce cayenne to 1/8 tsp.  Fresh cilantro is the key and add grilled chicken and avocado to make is a meal;-)

text:
I made this recipe last week for my carniferous husband and son, and vegan me.  It was a hit on all fronts, and I will most definitely make it again. Contrary to the taste of others, I thought two cans of black beans were just right. The beans add heartiness and more protein.  The only change I made was in the heat.  We're Texans, so I finely diced two jalapenos and a serrano, and added them to the saute mix, and doubled the cayenne pepper and cumin. YUM! (eta: edible quinoa isn't a grain - it's the seed of a grain)

text:
This is DELICIOUS. I didn't have any corn but that was okay. I added a couple of things; I added scallions because duh, scallions, and I boiled the beans separately. I put everything (except for the beans) together in my rice cooker and, for lack of a better term, I set it and forget it. When it was done I chopped up some avocado and tossed it with the quinoa and the beans. I also added a packet of sazon for color but the sazon isn't necessary. Color in my food, it's a Latin thing. I can't tolerate rice, this stuff is just perfect. In the morning (like today), I'll scramble an egg or two and mix it in and voila! Breakfast. Yessss.

text:
This is my go-to recipe when I have no idea who I'm cooking for-- lol! the cumin and quinoa are a superb combination. I like to leave out the corn and add a meat, like chicken or steak. I then use the leftovers for enchilada filling! It's the meal that keeps on giving... Top it off with avocado, fresh salsa, and some pepper jack cheese... everyone will be begging for more :)

P.S. Throw in that random zucchini, tomato, spaghetti squash.... whatever veggies might be left in the bottom of your fridge. They blend awesomely! I usually only use 1 can of beans because I only cook for two... but it's easy to make this a one-pot recipe your entire family will love!

text:
This recipe is perfect as is. Many people said they only used one can of beans? Well that means you took out a lot of flavor and fiber and ended up with a bunch of quinoa. I love typical black beans and rice cajun style so instead of corn try a can of diced tomatoes with green chilis and add a tsp of tumeric, the tumeric makes it taste exactly like the black beans and rice you will get in the south at restaurants and the tomatoes are a must at our house. Very good and healthy, this is now our regular Meatless Monday dinner!

text:
I love this dish! I read the reviews to get some tips. This is what I did differently.... I used olive oil instead of vegetable oil; and, I cut the black beans down to 1 can. I then added 1/2 c. Salsa to it. I've made this using either chicken broth or vegetable broth - it's great either way. I've also used canned corn instead of frozen - that works well too. When it's done, I've sqeezed some fresh lemon or lime juice on top to add to the flavor. 
TIP:  The dish is great fresh but it's even better once it's had a chance to sit for a while. The flavors marry together and mix well!

Rating:

dateLastModified:
2014-03-10T11:14:54.37
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
7626548
Display Name:
beachbound
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
685
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674154.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm not a very big cook, but I love reading and saving the recipes on here.  This is the first one that I made that I am actually writing a review for, it was great!!  I really like quinoa and have had multiple versions (homemade and restaurants) of it and this is by far my favorite.  The flavor was really so good, though with the sweetness of the corn I would add a little more cayenne.  I used coconut oil instead of vegetable oil (for health reasons) so had to saute the garlic (used onion powder since I didn't have an onion) on a lower heat.  I also didn't add any salt, used chicken stock (what I had), added a can of fire roasted diced tomatoes and a can of chopped artichoke hearts.  Didn't have any fresh cilantro so added some dried parsley.  I am SO glad I doubled the batch, I am going to enjoy this for lunch all week!

city:

None
country:
None
text:
This was great! When my other vegetarian meal didn't work out, this was a very quick, tasty save for our dinner. I halved it for my small family, and made it as written except I added a little bit of extra broth halfway through when it looked like it might burn before the quinoa was soft (and mine was done at 15 minutes). I used up a half can of southwestern corn instead of frozen (about 2/3c), and I used some parsley to bulk up the cilantro when I didn't have enough. The corn mix had a little red pepper in it, so I might add some diced red pepper in step one the next time; the color was very nice. It seemed very hot when I first tasted it, but the flavors mellowed after it sat for a couple of hours. I served it with the last of some sour cream and guacamole in flatbreads at room temperature, and it was delish!  This will be a go-to as I keep trying to serve more vegetarian meals. Thanks! UPDATE: the next day, I took about half the leftovers (about 1-1 1/2 c) and mixed them with half a can of black beans, mashed as smoothly as possible, one egg, and breadcrumbs (about 1/2-2/3 c., whatever is needed to reach consistency), and formed the mix into burgers (I got six, but yield will vary). I baked at 365, ten minutes per side, and they were delicious!

Good recipe. Instead of veggie broth, I juice 2-3 limes (3 if they're harder = less juice) put the lime juice in a measuring cup, then fill the rest of the way with water, up to the 1 1/2 cup mark. It makes it taste like Chipotle's lime rice. You're welcome! :D xoxo

text:
I love quinoa recipes!  It has a ton of protein, so it really is healthy.  I, too, rinsed the quinoa and used one can of beans, added yellow and orange bell pepper and chopped tomato for added nutrition and color, and I also added  a bit of powdered adobo seasoning for a bit of smoky flavor.  You could also use a teaspoon of canned adobo sauce.  But I found that what it really lacked was that pop of acid.  A healthy squeeze of lime juice on the finished dish really helped take it to the next level.  I freeze my quinoa dishes in 1 cup servings in ziplock freezer bags laid flat.  You can grab a frozen bag, smack it on the counter to break it up and zap it in the micro for a quick meal.  Throw in any diced or shredded meat you wish, if you are a carnivore.

city:

country:
None
text:
Delicious! Great recipe.  I made a batch for my co-workers to taste and they loved it!  

While it's best to rinse all grains before cooking, pre-washing is especially advisable for quinoa in order to remove the bitter white coating on its outer hull that sometimes remains after processing. To do so, simply run cold water over quinoa in fine-meshed strainer, gently rubbing the seeds with your fingers. (Avoid soaking quinoa, however, as the bitter coating can leach into the grain.) After rinsing, place one cup of quinoa and two cups of water in a covered pot and bring to a boil. Reduce heat and simmer for about 15 – 20 minutes, until the grains become translucent and the germ appears as a thin white ring around each grain. Fluff with a fork.

I usually cook extra quinoa and keep in the refrigerator for up to one week.  Just scoop out what you need for each recipe.  It's delicious cold, hot, in soups, wrap sandwiches, etc. 

Quinoa has the highest protein content of any grain.  It contains all nine essential amino acids, making it a complete protein.  With that in mind, it makes a good substitute for meat and is a less expensive, healthier choice.

This was excellent! I read a lot of the reviews which said to use only one can of black beans, so when I started this up, I opened only one can but had the second on hand just in case. After adding the first can of beans, I could see why some people were saying that adding the second would be too much. BUT! I had faith in the recipe and decided to add the second can anyway. My husband wouldn't stop raving about it! I will definitely be making this recipe again. And again. And again.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
So yummy and so easy to make! I have to admit, I was terrified of trying to cook quinoa for the first time... I thought it would be difficult and time consuming, but I'm surprised at how easy it actually was! I read through some of the comments before attempting and made only two changes. I added red pepper in with the onions (gave it good color and flavor!), and only used one can of black beans. Advice to new cookers (like me!), just because it says let it simmer for 20 minutes does not give you the excuse to not check in on it! I think mine would have been done after 12-15 minutes, and at 17 mins some of the onion, pepper, and quinoa were a bit burnt on the bottom. Oops! Now I know for next time, and there will most certainly be a next time. Gave this recipe to a coworker and she's excited to try it this weekend!

text:
WOW, yum yum yum!!  So, I hate making alterations to recipes before I've even tried them, but for this one I did just from reading others' comments and suggestions.  I cut up one red bell pepper and cooked it along with the onions and garlic.  Also, I used chicken broth.  When I began cooking the quinoa and had set it to simmer, I think I had it too low so the quinoa wasn't cooking, so I added about 1/2 cup more chicken broth, turned up the temp to low-medium, and cooked another 12 minutes.  After that, it was perfect!  When I "stirred" the quinoa, I actually kind of folded it over on itself to prevent it from becoming mushy and it worked great!  Added the corn, black beans and fresh cilantro and then squeezed juice of one lime.  Seriously, delicious!  I love how the sweetness of the corn goes well with the spice!  I will be making this over and over again!

text:
This recipe deserves more than five stars, for how great and versatile this quinoa dish is! It's a great spin off of the traditional rice and beans dish and goes great with most chicken dishes you can think of. The dish is somewhat bland (great for people who don't like spice, but if your like my family we like flavor but without burning our mouths), we remedied this by adding a touch more garlic and cilantro then called for and once paired with a flavorful chicken recipe is was great comfort food. The great thing about this comfort food is that people on a low carb diet, diabetic, or simply wanting to eat healthy (but tasty food) adults, teens, or children its a one stop wonder.

text:
This was such a great recipe! I like to tweak recipes to my liking, so this is what I did: First, I washed and soaked my quinoa for an hour, drained and set aside. I fried my onions until they were just getting soft, then threw in my chopped garlic to fry. (I put the garlic in after so it didn't burn.) I also chopped up half a jalapeno pepper really tiny (about the same size chunks as I had the garlic) and fried that as well. I added my quinoa to the mixture and fried it for a little while to get all the flavors melding together. I then added in water (in place of vegetable broth) and one chicken bouillon cube. I added in my cumin,cayenne (just a touch of cayenne because I already had jalapenos for heat - I didn't add any pepper), and salt (for those who are bad at estimating salt, one level teaspoon is what I used). Then I stirred, covered, turned down the head and let it simmer for 15 minutes. I then added half a can of black beans and half a can of corn (I like equal parts of beans, corn, and quinoa on my spoon). Stirred and let it simmer for another 5-10. And last but not least, I chopped up my cilantro and mixed that into the dish. TA-DA! Deliciousness in my mouth!
Review:
Rating:
5

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great meal in itself and was my first time making quinoa. I doubled the quinoa and soaked it in water for about 10-15 min because i prefer the quinoa soft. Sauteed crushed garlic cloves in the oil until they turned brown and discarded them before i added the onions.  Added a half a cup of diced mushrooms and a whole red bell pepper diced to the onions and sauteed for another 5-7 min and added a little salt.  Added the quinoa and about 3 and half cups of chicken stock along with the cumin and some paprika. Brought it to a boil and simmered for 20 min.  I let it cool before I added a can of corn, can of black beans, squirt of lemon and some fresh cilantro.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Served for our weekly Meatless Monday dinner, this was better than I expected. Quite flavorful for just a few ingredients, plus it was very filling.  It was also a hit with my DH, who is a self-professed black bean hater! I used a 5.46 oz bag of pre-washed roasted garlic quinoa (which was actually 3/4 c...score!) I used only 1 can of cumin & chili-spiced black beans, which jazzed up the flavor factor. I still added 1/2 tsp of cumin since I like it. I only used 1/8 tsp cayenne and still, my 4 year-old DD found it too spicy. Sadly, no fresh cilantro tonight, so I had to sub the dried stuff, but it was fine in a pinch. I highly recommend topping your portion with diced (or sliced) avocado....holy delicious! I'm SO looking forward to cold leftovers for lunch tomorrow! This will most definitely remain on the Meatless Monday rotation. Thanks for an excellent, healthy dinner!

text:
I like this recipe, just made it ten minutes ago! It was my first time and I didn't have black beans on hand, so I used Chili Beans instead, and used dried cilantro for fresh. Fresh would've definetely been better, and the quinoa also has a slight bitter taste, I would reccomend to wash it before you cook it. Next time I'll add tomatoes with lemon juice and real black beans, because I didn't get the fresh flavors but instead got a southern, American spice chili taste. (Chili beans!) but overall, yum. I'm glad it's so healthy and maybe it'll be better cold.

text:
This was my first time cooking quinoa.  I mostly followed the recipe as written with the following changes:  1 can black beans (that's all i had) and i was out of cayenne pepper so i added a mix of chilli pepper and paprika.  My husband and i ate and enjoyed.  This was a lot for two people, though and with some leftovers I made wraps.  I took some of this quinoa mix and added left over diced chicken (about 3/4 of a grilled boneless, skinless....it had been grilled with just oil, salt and pepper) and salsa.  Heated the entire mix and put it in a wrap.  We topped with guacomole and it was delicious. I don't have any measurements, just eyed it to out to our tastes.

Very good and easy recipes.  I had a lentil/quinoa mixture I used and good it in the vege broth separately. Then I sauteed the onions, garlic together with canola oil.  Once lightly browned I add the frozen corn and cooked it with the onion mixture. Added the black beans to the onion mixture; heated through then added the cooked, fluffed, quinoa/lentil mixture then add the cilantro.  Very good and healthy. High protein and fiber.

text:
I love it! Everyone I've made it for has loved it! This is a great recipe for quinoa and is extremely healthy. I would suggest reducing the amount of black beans if you make this exactly as printed, it will NOT look like the picture. The ratio of black beans is off. I think it's perfect with half the amount printed. This recipe is great because it's very forgiving if the ingredients aren't "just right" and it allows the cook to change it up easily to suit their taste. I love adding extra garlic (triple the amount) and quality paprika.

text:
I love this recipe! Its great for the warm summer months. I have made some changes.... I use 1/2 tsp cumin as opposed to 1tsp. and I only use a few shakes of cayenne. I use only one can of beans ( otherwise its like a black bean salad with some quinoa. I also use a whole box of frozen corn which probably equals 2 cups. I also just use chicken broth as I am not a vegetarian.    I have also added a couple extras to jazz it up a little for my daughter who didnt love it as much as I did..... I cut up an avacado add some  reduced fat feta and squeze some lime juice over it!!! ( I also ommit the cilantro in her portion since she is not a fan)  delicious- enjoy!!

text:
I'm pregnant and working and I've been looking for something nutritious that I can make on the weekend and take throughout the week for my lunches. This recipe was exactly what I was looking for. This is delicious and I love how healthy it is. I recommend only using one can of beans. After making it originally, I added an additional cup of quinoa cooked in just water because the beans were too overpowering. Also, I didn't have the spices listed so I've been adding sriracha to taste. For anyone interested in tampering a bit and trying something new, I highly recommend adding avocado, salsa, and some pepper jack cheese and using it as a dip for chips. Amazing!

text:
I give it five stars with some very simple additions.
I rinsed and then soaked the quinoa for 10 min. Meanwhile, I sauted the onion until translucent and then added the garlic until both were lightly browned. Because my family likes a little Xtra heat, I doubled the cayenne pepper and added a can of medium Rotel tomatoes with chilis. I also used a can of drained and rinsed corn rather than frozen.
We really liked it and will be making regularly. May add some blackened chicken.

Very suttle flavors to this recipe. I modified it a bit for fun. First I recommend soaking the quinoa for 30 minutes or more to reduce bitterness. I added kale this time I cooked it to make it a nutritional powerhouse and even the picky kids ate it! My husband added some "Voodoo sauce" to make it extra scipy. Next time I think I'll try switching out the corn with some red or yellow bell pepper and add some summer squash or zucchini instead. Great core recipe to be eaten as is or with substitution! A++ thanks!

country:
None
text:
I made this when we had company who are vegan, with a side of fried platains.  Yum!  I did leave out the cayenne to make it a little more kid-friendly.  We added tobasco to ours at meal-time and it was fantastic.   I would recommend using a 3 to 1 broth to quinoa ratio (ie 3 cups of broth for every 1 cup of quinoa).  This recipe says it makes 10 servings, which may be true if you are serving it as a side dish.  As a main course, it probably makes about 4-5 servings.

text:
great recipe - never cooked quinoa before altough I bought it twice, one bag of the regular kind and one bag of the red quinoa - I used the regular kind this time around = I did not use the corn (too hard on the colon), used chicken stock, and added half a red pepper and half a yellow pepper, diced right after the onnions and garlic had cooked- added to the mix some coriander that I had dried myself from fresh previously- at the end, added one tiny can of black beans, and 1/3 can of kidney beans - all came out superb - maybe too much cumin for my taste, but all in all, if I eat it cold, it will not feel so spicy - I really love the crunch of the quinoa and the added texture of the sweet peppers - very nutritional and once made, easy to just dig in if I open that fridge door looking for something comforting and interesting

text:
I made this last night and it was fabulous.  Plus, it fits so well into my busy schedule.  Took about 10 minutes to prep.  That means a lot, since my rule is, it can't take any longer to make than it takes to eat -- at least on weeknights.  :>)  This had a ton of flavor, spicy but not too spicy.  It could be a side dish or a main dish.  And quite frankly, for fiber and protein, I think I got my daily recommended amount just out of this one dish.  I only used one can of beans, since so many reviewers recommended that.  I could have used a few more, but not an entire can, so it wasn't worth opening another one.  I brought it to work today for lunch, since so many people said it tasted good cold.  If it does, this is definitely a dish I will do over and over.

I have been doing a lot of research to find different ways to use quinoa and this recipe came up.  And holy smokes batman it is DELICIOUS! I made this recipe for a family who just welcomed their baby girl home and needed something healthy and gluten free.  The only little things changed were I used only 1 can of black beans, used canned corn (drained) instead of frozen and added diced sugar plum tomatoes, red onion and freshly squeezed lime juice to take it up a notch. I thought the amount of seasonings that it called for were just right.  I also served it with shredded chicken over a bed of greens to make a complete meal out of it! LOVE!

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6415737.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Never had quinoa before and didn't know what to do with it... this was a perfect start. I sauteed the onions and garlic with a red pepper and added about a 1/2c of that to the boiling chicken broth & quinoa along with about 1/3c of soffrito. While that cooked I browned 1lb of ground chic breast seasoned with adobo, garlic powder, cumin, salt & pepper in canola oil. When the quinoa was done I poured the entire contents into the pan with the chicken and the sauteed veggies. I used 1 can of black beans and the leftover corn from our frig (about 1/2c or so). Mixed it all up. Seemed a little dry so I added another 1/2c of soffrito. It was yummy! Thanks for the inspiration :)

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614247.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
the first time i made this following the directions exactly and it turned out very good. However the black beans were too much and the over all consistency was too gooey for me. I made this dish again tonight with slights changes. 1 can black beans, one can corn, sauted the quinoa with the onions, garlic and spices for 3 minuts then added the vegitable broth. Heres where I changed things around a bit more. I boiled the quinoa for about 5 minutes before reducing the heat and covering it. I also put a paper towel under the cover to help absorb more moisture ( a trick most persians use when making basmati-jasmin rice) this helped it not have that muddy consistancy at the end. I also microwaved the beans and corn before stiring it in. Too much stiring can cause that muddyness again. Hope this review was helpful.

Made this a hundred times and it is tried and true.  I usually skip the corn and opt for chopped spinach and canned chicken instead (added when the corn is called for). I rarely have cilantro on hand, but when I do, it really sets this dish off!

text:
extremely simple and tasty recipe! i love quinoa, but this is the first time that i cooked it on the stovetop and mixed it with other ingredients. i didn't have any cumin so i added more cayenne pepper, and it give it a really good kick. i didn't include any fresh cilantro since i didn't have any on hand. also, like what others suggested, i used one can of black beans, and it was plenty. i used a cup of chicken broth instead of veggie broth, and it was the perfect amount as well. i nixed the salt since the broth already had sodium included. you can eat this as a healthy main dish, but i used it as a side dish along with some baked salmon. DELISH!

text:
I loved this recipe. Ive been wanting to try Quinoa for quite some time now, and this was the perfect opportunity. I cut out the corn because I dont believe there is any nutritional value in it, and replaced it with Lima beans and diced up carrots. It was phenomenal!

The only thing that I am interested about substituting is the broth. The sodium content in these cans of broth are outrageous, even the reduced sodium cans. Is there anything wrong with using water? Has anyone done that? I'm sure you could season it to taste. The meal is so healthy, it didn't feel right tasting that much salt content in it.

Aside from that, I served the dish with roasted string beans, sprinkled with parmesan and it was a huge hit. Excited to try it cold for leftovers tomorrow!

I don't usually rate a recipe when I haven't made it exactly as written. However the alterations I made likely made little difference in the outcome. This is by far one of the best quinoa dishes I've ever had! I made minor substitutions...used only one can of beans, used canned corn (didn't have frozen) and used dried coriander instead of fresh cilantro (also because I didnt have any on hand) I think the flavors would probably be close would I have made it just like it was written. Perfect texture, spice and sweetness!
