text:
I was looking for a different way to use up some of my quinoa and came across this one, basically decided to try it because of the number of positive reviews, which I will add to.

I followed the recipe to the T - except, I added green peppers (which were delicious), no extra salt, and didn't have chili flakes so used chili paste instead for a kick. I didn't have cilantro, too bad, would have been nice.

I wouldn't have thought of making such a dish but am now glad I did - it is a fresh view of the typical rice and beans and also a fresh view on quinoa. Highly recommend especially since you can make it your own.

text:
This is a great basic recipe for the newly-exploring 'granola' eater.  Having converted away from processed foods and only eating "real" food for many years, I added on to this one.  I added zucchini and Kale to the quinoa mixture prior to covering and simmering.  I also subbed the corn for edamame.  I also added 1/2 a jar of roasted (in garlic and olive oil) red peppers I had on hand.  Because I added more "stuff", I doubled the spices.  This is a great one, especially for a filling lunch after a hard yoga class.

I made this last week and it was so good I ate it almost every day. It's super easy and super quick to make, I scaled it down for one serving and used about 2 Tbsp quinoa. It's very important to soak your quinoa for about 15 minutes before you cook it, or at least rinse it to make it fluffier. This recipe will definitely keep you "regular" if you know what I mean with all that fiber! Super good, I'm going to be making this again very soon!

text:
I think this was the first dish I tried with quinoa, and I love it! I like that it's very adaptable to whatever you want... you can add or take away veggies, change up the spices (I sometimes will add my homemade taco seasoning), etc. If you don't like cilantro (I love it, but hubby hates it), the dish is still good without it. I also use chicken broth, because that's the only think I keep on hand. This is perfect as a side dish or a main dish, hot or cold! And unlike many salad-type dishes, this one keeps well in the fridge.

text:
This is an excellent, easy recipe.  It keeps well in the refridgerator - and actually tastes even better the next day.  You can dial up or down the heat (cayenne) according to your tastes.  I use more heat for my husband and I and less if the kids are eating it.  I add other veggies that I have on hand and want to use (peppers, tomato, etc), but it is great as is as well.  You can use 1 or 2 cans of beans, depending on your taste preference.  I love the flavor and heat of this recipe!  It works as a side dish, salad, main course, appetizer, etc.

text:
Delicious! I made this for some friends who are on the RAVE diet- so I sauteed the veggies in a little sherry and water (no oil allowed on RAVE). I also added some red cabbage and red peppers and doubled the seasoning. For non-vegans its great with some sour cream and/or shredded cheddar.  I served it as a main dish with whole wheat pita bread and a green salad. Leftovers are great hot or cold the next day! highly recommended.

This is amazing!!   I had never heard of quinoa until one day it was on the Dr. Oz show.  I then searched allrecipes and found this recipe.  I followed this recipe exactly the first time I made it, then changed it up the next few times.  I add lots of other veggies to it, red, orange, yellow and green bell peppers, frozen sweet peas, zucchini - I also like to put it in a bowl or on a plate, top with shredded mexican blended shredded cheese (or taco blend) and zap it in the microwave to melt the cheese then sprinkle on Frank's Red Hot sauce - it's SO GOOD!!  Absoultely delightful!!  Thank you so much for sharing this recipe!!

I use either olive oil or no oil at all when I do this recipe and I leave the liquid from the black beans in the recipe. Some alternate ingredients I have tried is using tomato bouillion to make the veggie broth and lipton's veggie soup mix (so I dump the salt) instead of the veggies. This is great to do when I am at work because I can't chop veggies and the soup makes a decent substitute. If I use the soup and bouillion, I use 4 cups of water and 2 cups quinoa. At home, this recipe is perfect just like it is written!

This recipe was very delicious. The only thing I changed was the amount of oil to saute the onions and garlic, and the amount of vegetable broth. I used only one tablespoon vegetable oil and then sprayed the pan with cooking spray (for less fat content). I also used a whole a 14.5 ounce can of vegetable broth because my quinoa was not softening up as it should. Other than, this was a great and tasty recipe for my dieting needs. Definitely 5 stars!

Excellent! Made this last night and my picky husband really liked it. He was turned off at first by how it looked--said it looked like boiled bird seed. However, once he tasted it he changed his mind. Made the following revisions - used jalapeno-infused grapeseed oil instead of vegetable oil, omitted onion (hubby & I don't like), used all natural chicken broth (didn't have veggie broth on hand), and southwest style frozen corn. Really pleased with the way it turned out. Husband went back for seconds. Will definitely make this again.

Very tasty vegan meal. I gave it 5 stars for being the perfect food  - low fat, low cal, high fiber, high protein, fairly inexpensive and filling without making you feel bloated. This is the perfect meal to make after maybe a weekend of eating more extravagant meals. I made this as a main dish, served with a salad and red wine. Yum!  I've been wanting to make quinoa for awhile now because I've read so much about the health benefits.  This recipe was so easy to make and turned out delicious!  I wanted to serve this as a cold salad, so I let it chill for awhile and also added fresh lime juice to it.  So fresh! (I did try this warm, and it was very good served warm too.  I just prefer it as a cold salad).

text:
We liked this, but didn't love it - we used it as burrito fillings, with cheese and Frank's Red Hot.  The acid in the Frank's really helped; I think if I made it again, I'd add a squeeze of lime or lemon to brighten things up a bit.  I followed the recipe exactly, with two minor technique modifications:  I added the spices to the pan when the onions were half-cooked, hoping to bring out the flavors a bit more, and added the beans with the corn so they'd heat through.  I think part of the problem was that I used canned black beans; I always do, but I think for this recipe it might be worth making my own, since the beans are pretty much straight-out-of-the-can.  Thanks for the recipe!

I have made this before and the family loved it!  I thought the recipe was great just how it was, but I'm making it tonight and thought I'd try some of the suggestions - red bell pepper, olive oil, one can of beans.  What I did with it the last time I made it was make enchilladas out of some of it.  I shredded some boiled chicken breast, added it to the mixture, wrapped it in tortilla shells, placed it in a baking dish and poured enchillada sauce and some shredded cheddar cheese over the top.  I baked at 350 til the enchillada shells were baked and the cheese melted.  I can't remember how long, but I think between 30-45 minutes.

text:
Easiest Quinoa recipe I've ever made! I added a bit of chopped celery with the corn to add some extra crunch. My boyfriend loved it! Easy to make substitutions, such as peas or diced red pepper instead of corn. Add some tofu, lean fish, chicken breast,nuts or beaten egg (at the last second) to up the protein. For the fresh cilantro I sustituted the tube style herbs, much better than dried! Also, used college inn low sodium chicken broth instead of a salty vegetable broth, to keep it blood pressure friendly.  We will definitely make this again!

text:
This dish was rather disappointing.  I can't help but think that the proportions are off!  I followed the recipe exactly except using 1/2 of the black beans called for.  It turned out soupy and I had to cook off the excess moisture, which then turned the dish rather mushy.  It had great flavor, but the texture was off.  I think next time I'm going to use 1 C of broth to 3/4 C dry quinoa, which is what quinoa recipes usually call for.  And definitely use 1/2 of the black beans called for.

text:
This was the first time I had worked with Quinoa.  One important thing to note, I did not see mentioned in the recipe, make sure you thoroughly wash the quinoa before you cook it to wash off the bitter coating.  The only changes I made to this was I shaved the kernels off fresh ears of corn, and I added diced tomatoes.  It was quite delicious.  As I am discovering quinoa seems to takes on and absorbs the seasoning and flavors of the food it is cooked with very well.  I really couldn't discern it's own individual flavor.  It looks to be a very promising grain to work with.

text:
We love this! I needed a quick recipe to make and take to a party and I didn't want to go to the store and buy ingredients. Luckily I had the quinoa in the cabinet along with everything else. I'd been looking for a recipe that used quinoa and appealed to me for quite soem time.  I was very pleased to stumble across this.  It was quick and easy. I took another reviewers advice and soaked the quinoa for a bit.  It was a big hit at the party. It does make a lot so we had leftovers. No one seemed to mind. My 4 year old and 1 year old both loved it.  I've mad it again several times since and have enjoyed it each time.  Depending on my taste for the day, I do add a bit more cumin and adjust the cayenne. If it's too hot the kids won't eat it. This is a great recipe and definitely recommend it!!

text:
This recipe showed up just in time for my post Labor Day vow to eat healthy.  The combination of the cayenne and fresh cilantro was delicious.  I used red pepper flakes instead of cayenne, as I feel it's a little easier to control the heat and went a little easy on the pepper.  You can always add more later. I didn't have vegetable broth, so used a small individual serving can of V-8 juice and added water to make up the rest of the liquid.  The only other change was just one can of black beans.  I found that to be plenty for me.  I'll definitely make this again.  This recipe lends itself to lots of changes with different vegetables, grains, etc.

text:
Wow.  My first time cooking with quinoa, and it is so very good.  Just a few notes--I'm from a small town, so it took me a while to find quinoa--it was only sold at my local food co-op/health food store.  I soaked the quinoa for 20 minutes and rinsed it twice because some non-boxed quinoa apparently can have a bitter flavor from not being rinsed.  (I learned this from asking a woman at the co-op how she prepares quinoa.  The quinoa there is located in food bins, not pre-packaged boxes.)  I added some tomatoes with green chilis at the end, and those made it too spicy, but that's my fault.  Other than that, I kept it as is, and it is fantastic!  Thank you so much for this recipe!

text:
This is a great recipe!  I did make some modifications based on what I actually had in my cupboard and on other user recos.  I used Trader Joe's Harvest Grains Blend (1/2 bag), as it does have some quinoa mixed in, and I didn't have quinoa.  I followed the package for cooking time and broth measurements      (1 3/4 cups chicken broth and 10 minutes). I used only 1 can of black beans, added in 1 can of diced tomatoes, and omitted the cilantro b/c I didn't have any. It was delicious!  My husband, 17 month old son (fairly picky eater) and friend loved it! I've made this a few times, and it's a great side dish.  I've also eaten it for lunch by itself as it's very hearty.

I thought this was a tasty, nutritious side dish. My first time cooking with quinoa.  I used only 1/2 of an onion, 1 1/2 cloves garlic, used chicken broth instead of vegetable, italian parsley instead of cilantro and only 1 can of the beans. I thought this was really good and I will definitely cook it again.

text:
I've been eating this for years, it's one of my favorite staple foods--however I don't bother sauteing the onions/garlic--I don't think you need to unless you just can't stomach raw garlic and onions.  In fact I don't cook anything but the quinoa, and for the last two minutes of cooking it, I throw in the frozen corn and it comes out fine.  Then just let it cool, throw it all together, and pour the dressing on--saves time and it's very delicious.

text:
Even better than I had expected. After searching all over, I found my quinoa at Trader Joe's (organic market). I used fat free/low sodium chicken broth instead of the veg broth. I increased the cayenne pepper (like it spicy) and only added 1 can of drained/rinsed black beans (thought that was more than enough). Loved the flavors of the cumin and the fresh cilantro...a must add for the freshness factor. I ate this as a main dish with some organic cherry and grape tomatoes (red,yellow,orange,and
green). Delicious.....this is my first time with quinoa and won't be my last, this is a healthy and hearty dish.....even my 1/2c. serving (I'm currently maintaining on Weight Watchers)was completely satisfying. Good,healthy, organic and full of fiber to fill you. Thanks for a great recipe!!

text:
This was just okay.  Nothing special.  I have made it twice. The first time I followed the recipe but only used one can of black beans.  I agree with others that one can is enough.  I was the only one to eat it in my house so each time I ate it I tried variations, the original as is, with salsa, with fresh tomatoes.  Something missing.  The second time I made it I doubled the recipe and used 1/2 V8 juice and 1/2 beef broth to cook it in.  I also added crushed red peppers and some Italian seasoning. I will continue to make this, primarily because of the nutrition and calorie factor (trying to lose those darn 10 lbs I gained in the last year).  I think next time I will use spicy V8 and maybe try some worchester sauce and play with some spices.  Of note, I do think it always tastes a wee bit better the next day and it does make a quick easy lunch for work.

I am trying to eat healthier but want to enjoy my favorite tastes.  I love rice/beans/corn combinations in tortilla wraps and I could tell I would like this and I was not disappointed.  Quinoa is something I am new to but I love grains so I wanted to try it. I found it at my health food store although I mispronounced it when I asked for it. I liked it in the wraps, but it was even better using corn tortillas fried crisp and left flat like a tostada.  I topped them with fresh tomato and shredded cheese. I used 1 can of black beans as previous reviewer's had suggested and used granulated onion powder instead of real onion so the husband would eat it. This was amazing, easy and quick!!!  I did use chicken broth, what I had, and a full bulb of garlic, we are garlic lovers.  I also waited to add the garlic until shortly before adding the broth.  Because I watched the video, I learned that I should rinse the quinoa to remove the oils that can make it bitter.  That was a great help!  Love the tips in the recipe videos!  My husband loved this and I will definitely be making it again.  I will probably give some of the review suggestions a try as well, but definitely yummy just as it is.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made as directed and it turned out great! I used dried black beans so I had to soak overnight, then cook the beans. Canned beans come already cooked. Since the corn was frozen and the beans were not warm, I feel like the dish could have been hotter. You can’t really cook it for much longer when you add those ingredients because all of the liquid is gone. Needs more salt than I added, and could use something extra to top it. We topped ours with slices of avocado and Himalayan sea salt. It was delicious! The avocado added just the right amount of fat.

text:
So yummy! Made some minor adjustments... Here’s what I did: I added 1 teaspoon of dried oregano with spices listed. I also omitted the corn (my son doesn’t like it) but used a diced red pepper instead. I put this in after quinoa was cooked. I also added a can of roasted, diced tomatoes with garlic (and all its juices). I added the can at the same time as the red pepper. I let this simmer to help soften the red pepper a bit. That’s it! My husband and son both devoured it!!! Super yummy. :)

text:
Loved this recipe!
I agree with 2 previous reviewers suggestions: 
1) only one can of beans is necessary 
2) cook the quinoa and spices separately, and add it at the end with the beans and cilantro.
Also, I separate out a partial batch without cilantro for my family members who have that gene that makes it taste like soap. Me - I can’t get enough!

text:
I already had some basic quinoa made so I wanted to spice it up. This was perfect. I just added about a half cup of broth and didn’t need to let it simmer the whole 20 minutes. I only had one can of black beans but kept all the same amount of spices and added in about a cup of the cooked quinoa. I served it in a bowl with a scoop of mild organic salsa on the side to help cool it down, then put some avocado on top. Loved it and now there’s some left over for the next couple of days.

I made half the recipe, just the two of us, and it's plenty, plus left overs.  I sauteed the onions then added the quinoa and let it toast a bit then added the garlic,  I used a can of red kidney beans, because that's what I had, and added a can of green chili's. text:
Mmmmmmmmm!  This isn’t the kind of dish I’d normally make but since the only ingredient I had to buy was cilantro I decided to give it a try.  I used homemade turkey stock instead of vegetable and one can of black beans, those were my only changes.  I was surprised at how much of a kick the 1/4tsp of cayenne brought to this dish - I’m glad I didn’t go with my instincts and add more!  Absolutely delicious.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2945318.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made some modifications, but this was delicious. Started everything as instructed (heavy on the garlic), but instead of straight Quinoa, I got the Minute Rice Quinoa & Wild Rice mixture... two envelopes of that required more vegetable broth than above, but I just eyeballed it... maybe 2 1/2 cups? Also, changed the add-ins to one can of black beans and one can of corn. Added some covered cooking time in 5 minute increments until the rice/quinoa was the desired tenderness, I think it as a total of 25 or 30 minutes. Finally, added dried parsley instead of fresh cilantro (we don’t like cilantro) and added about 4 oz of Feta cheese in the last 5 minutes which bound everything together and smoothed out the taste. Delicious!

text:
I recently discovered a Southwest Black Bean Quinoa mix by a company called Urbane. The store I bought it at can't ever keep it in stock, so I was desperate to find a replacement. Enter: This recipe. I made it exactly as written (reduced it by half), and it's freaking PERFECT. Reminds me of a Cafe Rio or Qdoba or Chipotle burrito mix. I put mine on a whole wheat tortilla with some cheese and sour cream and it makes for the best vegetarian burrito ever.

text:
I’m so excited to find this recipe! Everyone in the family likes it, it’s healthy, its easy. It’s a make-ahead and reheat, and definitely make extra for leftovers. Like others, I rinsed the quinoa—something I wish I’d known a long time ago—and there wasn’t any bitterness, and I increased the spices, garlic, and onion to 1-1/2 the recommended amount and it’s just right. I added half a cup of medium chunky salsa along with the cilantro—it gave it just a hint of tomato and I’m sure I’ll be trying many more variations in the future. It’s a keeper.

text:
This is great side dish!  I made a few changes based on past cooking experience.  I set aside about a 1/4 cup of uncooked, minced onions and soaked them in red wine vinegar.  Then after cooking the quinoa and letting it cool off, I strained the uncooked onions and added them to the quinoa along with black beans and canned corn.  The vinegar soaked onions gives this dish a little zest and texture :)

I tripled the garlic and added garlic and onion powder as well.  ONE CAN OF BEANS IS ENOUGH.  I actually wanted to taste the quinoa.  We'll definitely be adding this to our regular side dishes.

text:
WOW,  Today is the first day of our vegan diet and I choose this meal as your main dish. I'm very full now. I didn't even know what quinoa was.  I didn't add all the corn because I'm not crazy about it. I also added a can of rotella instead of the second can of beans.  I added some fresh oregano. I also added a lot more water while it was cooking because it didn't seem like it was tender enough.  Many reviewers  said it need more flavor so I made sure there was enough cumin, salt and pepper.  I added the cumin late but not sure if that made a difference.  At the end I served fresh cut tomato's and lots of avocado on the top. My boyfriend SHOCKED me when he said it's one of the best meals I have ever made including all the beef and chicken that he loves so much.  I can't wait to make it again.

userID:

Display Name:
Julie Lutz
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4901296.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
There is no where on the directions where it says to soak the quinoa. Unless you watch the video, then it briefly mentions something about soaking it but even then it’s so quickly said you may miss it. This has a lot of things in it that are normally very hard without cooking a LONG time. The black beans, the quinoa and even the frozen corn. So to throw this stuff in a pan and not have it already cooked a little makes it come out quite crunchy or in my opinion....disgustingly hard. They call it “aldente”. I call it uncooked and nasty. So although this was a HUGE problem for me....I still opt to give this recipe 4 stars bc I don’t want to discourage anyone from making this. It has very good seasonings and tastes wonderful aside from the hard thing I just explained. So if I made it wrong....I apologize. I don’t know how I could have not made it correct though because I followed the instructions well and to the “t” so to speak. Idk what else to say. lol.  Good recipe. Just know that if you like your veggies cooked and not hard and gross you should maybe precook some of these ingredients first.

It was so delicious and simple.  I did use 1 can of kidney beans and only 1 can of black beans because I didn't realize the one was red until too late!  I  like the black beans better, but for a huge crowd and doubled or tripled recipe,  I think I'll substitute one can of red beans for the color.  I also added 1 tablespoon of lime juice same time as the frozen corn plus garnished with a chopped avocado, borrowing from another recipe.  I can see where the additions weren't absolutely needed, but my husband and I really liked these additional flavors!  Plan to make this for a party coming up!

text:
I substituted vegetable broth for two teaspoons of Mrs.Dash with two and a half tablespoons extra of water. Soaked in hot water and strained. That was vegetable broth. As other reviews, I increased the quinoa by 1/2 cup. I put the beans and  quinoa in at the same time. Oops. Then... I read the reviews one I dumped the beans in out of sequence. It was a hit and loved by all at my work potluck. This dish was cleaned out.. Mixing the beans with quinoa together gave it a bit of a texture change (smooth) and blended the flavours together. I will try this recipe again, and cook quinoa first. I believe it will be a completely different experience . Enjoy!

text:
First time making Quinoa.
Somewhat disappointed with the grain as it does not swell up at all. This recipe is useful as a side dish - not a main Vegan course. I was not impressed overall.
Suggest limiting diced onion to 1/2 cup.
Suggest limiting cayenne to 1/4 tsp per recipe - or less. I like spicy food and this recipe is pretty spicy as it is.
Cumin amount is perfect.
I used only one  15 oz can of black beans and it was enough.
Did not add Cilantro as I detest it's taste.

text:
YUM! I used all organic, non GMO ingredients. My only substitute was chicken broth instead of vegetable just because that is what I had in the fridge. It was easy, inexpensive (even going organic) and SUPER tasty. I loved the kick the cayenne pepper gave while complimenting the sweet corn. I am wondering if some of the folks that gave a bad review didn't rinse the beans? It really is a must do! Play with the amount of seasoning as you go along! I added garlic and onion powder as it is my belief that you can't go wrong with a little extra of both. Thank you for this wonderful and healthy recipe!

userID:

Display Name:
seben
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3054158.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My husband and I love this dish.  
I use a cup of quinoa to two cups of water. 
I use canned sweet yellow corn in place of the frozen corn.
One can of black beans.
I use red pepper instead since I normally don't have cayenne pepper in the house.  I add it after the quinoa is cooked, and taste as I mix it in to our liking - we like it a spicier than the recipe gives.  
I also add more garlic and onion for more flavor. 
We normally allow it to cool in the refrigerator before serving for optimal flavor.   
I have made this many times and only once did it not turn out because I over cooked the quinoa and it was pretty mushy.  This is a go to meal for us, as its quick, easy and fairly cheap!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Frozen corn comes in a 12 oz package.  Since I didn't want leftover corn, I used the whole package.  I increased the quinoa to 1 cup and the veg broth to 2 cups.  I used a large Dutch oven on the stove so that it would easily hold it all and I would be able to mix it.  I added extra broth as needed so it wouldn't be too dry.  I used cilantro.  If you're not a fan of cilantro, you could use parsley instead, or maybe half of each.  For me this is a very good main dish, and I will be making it again.  Also, I used 2 cans of rinsed black beans and I browned a large chopped onion and then added the garlic.  It's very good !

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This was fantastic! My bf didn't think he would like quinoa but he thought it was great too.  I rinsed the quinoa, though with much difficulty because my mesh strainer wasn't fine enough, so I resorted to swirling the quinoa in water and draining as carefully as possible.  I added bell peppers  (one half) to the onion, (half), then garlic.  Then added the quinoa with some tomato chicken broth (1-1.5 tsp granules). After the quinoa was almost done at 20 min, I added  shredded chicken (1-2 c), chopped tomatoes (2, could try a can of diced ), half a can corn, and 1 can of black beans.  I omitted the cayenne for my taste.  Sprinkled with cheese and sour cream to serve, would be great without it or just cheese (cheddar/mont jack).  Will make again for sure!

None
text:
Great recipe that needs a bit of refining: Halve the amount of beans, double the spices, consider using smoked paprika instead of cayenne, and add 1/2-1 tsp of turmeric. Also, when cooking quinoa, always rinse and soak it for 30 mins, then drain before using. Do this and you'll have no bitter or grassy taste, and the cooking time is shortened.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an excellent starter recipe.   I use 1 cup quinoa  2 cups water.  Add 2 smashed garlic cloves.  Cook 15 minutes.   Sauté 1/2 red onion, chopped garlic, chopped carrots in olive oil.  Add 1 tsp. cumin, dash of chayanne, salt, pepper after veggies are sautéed.  Drain beans and 1 can chopped tomatoes.  Mix all together when quinoa is done removing smashed garlic from the quinoa. Mix in cilantro if you have on hand.   I've also added chopped green chilies.

text:
I've made this 3 times and it's now part of the weekly rotation. Like other reviewers I only used 1 can of black beans. I also added a can of Mexican style stewed tomatoes and a tablespoon of dried oregano, and substituted paprika for the cayenne pepper since my girlfriend doesn't like spicy. I combine the corn, beans, and tomatoes, and season with the oregano and paprika and cook in the microwave until heated through, then add the quinoa. I also add the cumin and quinoa to the onion mixture and let it cook a minute or 2 before adding the vegetable stock.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just love this dish and have made it 4 or 5 times, twice this week alone. Being a vegetarian, I am always in search of quality protein alternatives. This dish is so delicious as directed, cold or hot, but I used red quinoa, some chopped red bell peppers, a dab of sour creme and 1/4 or so avocado. It is so flavorful and nutritious. You can eat it as a main course or as an appetizer with some crunchy low cal chips, or even pile it on a tostada shell. It's very "Tex-Mex" fresh. Don't forget the cilantro if you like it...it makes it so delish.  Make sure to properly rinse and drain (a few times) the quinoa through a fine sieve before adding to the pot.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the recipe we've been looking for!  Simple and functional and healthy. After reading the reviews, we made the following variations to the recipe and it came out delicious! We rinsed the quinoa first. We doubled the batch for leftovers, so we used the two cans of black beans and doubled the quinoa (we used tri-color). We used 4c of vegetable broth when all was said and done for cooking the quinoa. We upped the ground cumin and cayenne pepper. We added a can of fire-roasted diced tomatoes. At the end, we squeezed lemon into our individual  bowls as well as added chopped/crumpled feta cheese. We also sprinkled more cilantro on top. Amazing depth. Yum!

text:
I LOVE this recipe! My husband thought he didn't like quinoa until I made this dish for him. Now he asks me for this all the time! 
Here are our changes to the recipe though:
•We use the water that you typically drain out of the corn and bean cans instead of broth.
•We add lightly-seasoned shredded chicken.
•We eat it with tortilla chips for a little crunch and extra saltiness.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677176.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this salad and make it regularly. I made a few adjustments to it to make it perfect for my taste. I cook the quinoa in chicken broth with salt, pepper, cumin and a drizzle of olive oil in a pot first. Then I let it rest for about 15 min. In a seperate pan, I saute the onions and garlic, then add the corn and black beans. I add a pinch of salt, pepper and cumin into this mix as well. Once it is cooked, I combine the mix with the quinoa and let it cool off before I finally add the cilantro into it. I add  half a lemon or lime juice as a final step. Delicious!

country:
None
text:
I have made this several times. It's 5 stars with the few tweaks I give it. I used 1 can of corn instead of 1 cup and only used 1 can of beans like a lot of folks suggested. If you like beans I'm sure it would be just fine with 2 cans. I also squeezed half a lime into it once it was done cooking and I like tripled the amount of cilantro (love that stuff). Once I put it in a bowl to serve I garnished it with a small lime wedge, some avocado and a dollop of plain Greek yogurt. I absolutely love this dish with those additions, I prepared it exactly as stated once and found it bland and boring. Thanks for this recipe, it will be enjoyed in our home for many years.

text:
My husband and I loved this! We often have Quinoa as a side dish and sometimes I add some vegetables into the Quinoa (peas etc). In this recipe I used only one can of beans and there was still more than enough for both of us. I also used chicken broth as I had no veggie broth at the time.  I used frozen peas instead of corn as I'm not a lover of corn. I did not soak the Quinoa beforehand, instead I do as i always do and held the strainer  with the Quinoa in it and ran the water from the tap over it for about three or four minutes making sure it was well washed. Always works for me. Will be having this again for sure!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe exactly as stated except I used fire roasted frozen corn. It probably didn't make any difference in taste but that's what I had on hand.  I hesitated about adding two cans of black beans as several reviewers thought it was too much but I always want to make the recipe as stated to give an honest opinion.  Looking at the cooked Quinoa then looking at two freshly rinsed cans of beans I wondered if I should add all of it. 
Well "we" say DO IT.
It blended very well and evenly and in our 7 opinions the two cans were “right on.”
The black beans didn't overtake the dish or taste and it looked beautiful. There was a little spiciness to it due to the cayenne pepper and the browning of the onions and garlic gave the Quinoa a nice flavor. The cilantro is a definite. It added an additional flavor that was very good. This was a great recipe and we decided we could make burritos with any left overs and change it up by adding some tomatoes and jalapeños to it. Thoroughly enjoyed it, thank you for posting the recipe, I can agree with others it is a five star!

text:
It was my first time ever making quinoa and this recipe totally rocked! Will definitely make again!
I did follow a few of the reviewers' advice and washed my quinoa before cooking. Afraid of turning my quinoa into mush, I cooked it separately and then carefully folded in the veggie mixture afterwards. 
Instead of using frozen or canned corn, I grilled fresh corn and cut them off the cobb. Also I only used one can of beans as two would have been overkill. I did not have cayenne pepper nor was it available at my grocery so I used a bit of sriracha instead. Came out great!

text:
This is great. Super flavorful. I followed the other reviewers suggestions and made the following changes. I added in 1/2 red pepper and 1/2 yellow pepper to onion and garlic. I also added the juice of a can of stewed tomatoes and used vegetable broth to make 1.5 cups of broth. I used garbanzo beans instead of black beans and added the cut up stewed tomatoes in the end. Love the flavor and taste. Can't wait for leftovers.

5/15/17 - made this again tonight, but made it a cold salad. Cooked the quinoa and let it cool. Then added one can of black beans, 1/4 cup red onion, 1 cup corn, 1/4 red or yellow pepper, cilantro, and cumin. I loved the crunch of the raw onions and peppers. I also topped it with an avocado. Really yummy.

I just can't even... I mean seriously... THIS. IS. FANTASTIC!!! I've tried umpteen amounts of quinoa recipes to try & incorporate healthier foods and NONE have come CLOSE to tasting this great. I added a bit more cayenne since Hubby & I like spicy. It didn't take away from the flavor at all. Hubby also used all my lime so that wasn't added and even without - very tasty and delicious. Testament to the flavor is Hubby is eating it right out the pan, hasn't waited for me to plate it! PLEASE - if you've never made quinoa - RINSE IT BEFORE COOKING. Great recipe as is that will be made again & again. I can't wait to try it with avocado.

text:
I added quite a bit to this recipe, my favorite thing being mangoes. Yum!! I only used one can of beans, and added chopped mangoes and a bell pepper. The mangoes give it a great sweetness that goes well with the onions. The white quinoa I used didn't fluff up quite as much as I thought it would, but the rest of the ingredients kept it hearty enough that I didn't feel like it was missing anything (even with less beans). The spices were great, and really boosted the flavor. Next time I make this, I will definitely use mangoes again, and maybe add some avocado.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674168.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Liked this a lot.  I added more cumin (1/2 T) and cayenne (1/2 tsp) and probably could have used more.  I thought the 2 cans of black beans were just right.  Most people think of veggies as being the "small" part of their meal, but it really should be the major part; the grain should be less.  Corn is a grain too, so it's best to add the second can of beans for a well-rounded healthy meal.  I think 15 min prep time is not correct.  Preparing the cilantro (plucking from stems, washing, drying and chopping) took 15 minutes!  Worth it though.

I made this last night for 4 adults and 2 children.(children 9 & 11yrs) My father can't eat corn so I substituted red bell pepper. Used 1 can of black beans as other reviewers suggested. Oh, also used Chili powder instead of cayenne because that's what I had. It was a huge hit, going to make again and again. Super healthy and low in calories.

text:
Every intention of making this recipe as written; however, I was missing ingredients.  Here's what I put in:
Garlic powder in place of garlic cloves
Beef broth in place of vegetable broth
1/8 tsp of cayenne
Canned chili beans (rinsed and drained) in place of black beans
Canned corn in place of frozen corn

I think I would have preferred the black beans, but it was still very good with chili beans - just had more of a chili flavor.  Thank you for the recipe!

text:
I didn't have frozen corn so I drained a can of whole kernel corn and put it in a heated & oiled cast iron pan to get some of the moisture out of it. I also drained and rinsed the only 1 can of black beans and added them to the corn to heat through along with cumin, salt, pepper, and garlic powder before adding it to the quinoa mixture. I served it with beef fajitas and sangria.

text:
I was a little reluctant to try this recipe because of all the rice and bean recipes I've tried with cumin and cayenne pepper... the spices always seemed to be far too strong. This recipe, however, is perfect! The ratio of spices is just right - not at all bland but not overpowering in the slightest. I only used one can of beans and upped the corn to 1.5 cups to partially make up for it. My husband, my 13-month-old and I all just gobbled it up! This is definitely one that I will make again and again. Thank you 3LIONCUBS!!! :)

text:
We tend to eat mostly vegetarian and this is our go-to taco filling.  We usually cut back on the beans to 1 can and add extra cilantro because we like it so much.  I will typically use some chipotle powder if we're in the mood for some more spice.  We also use 1 cup quinoa and a whole 15 oz can of vegetable broth.  Also use olive or coconut oil instead of vegetable oil.  Little modifications aside, this is a great side but stands out for us as taco filling and I eat it cold on top of a salad the next day since it always makes leftovers.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674149.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I loved this recipe so much! It is quick and easy to make, although I would make it without cilantro next time as its flavour doesn't go well with the spices. I also did not follow the recipe directions the same. I first started out by cooking my quinoa in water and while that was cooking I sautéed my onions and garlic. NOTE: Put your garlic in when your onions are halfway done cooking of the garlic will burn!. Once the quinoa was done I put it into a large bowl, added the onion.garlic mixture, my corn, and I used kidney beans because I did not have black beans, I added my spices and cilantro. I decided to mix it all together and put it in the fridge to eat it chilled and let the flavours marry. Overall it was a lovely recipe, just next time I will not be using cilantro.

text:
Made this yesterday and we loved it! Here's what I changed: subbed evoo for veg oil, added and cooked mushrooms before putting in the quinoa, mixed the seasoning together (added 1 tsp oregano, used 1 tsp of salt and pepper too) and stirred it into the onion/garlic mixture to coat before adding quinoa. Added rotisserie shredded chicken when the corn and beans go in. Used 1 can of beans only. Topped with avocado, Tapatio, and sour cream. It was perfect.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1115132.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yummy!  I took an excellent recipe (thanks 3LIONCUBS) and bent it to my needs.  After softening the onions, I added the spices to toast, adding an extra 1/2 tsp of cumin since I'm a fan. I then added 1lb of very lean ground beef.  Once browned, I added the rinsed (and patted dry) quinoa to the skilled to toast.  Due to the extra volume and since I don't like my quinoa too crunchy, I added 1 1/2 cups of beef broth and 1/2 cups of water.  I exchanged 1 can of pinto beans for 1 of the cans of black beans since that is what I has on hand.  A very delicious dinner!  Next time I may add 2 tsp of cumin and use cooked chicken.  This is such a simple recipe with so much potential for change. It has been added to my monthly rotation, a high honor indeed considering the sheer number of highly rated recipes at Allrecipes.

text:
What a terrific recipe and a tasty way to consume the very healthy quinoa!! The recipe gets five stars - stand alone!  I did use chicken stock instead of vegetable stock, and I found that I needed to add a little more while the quinoa was simmering to keep it moist.  I really like black beans, so I used two cans. This comes down to personal taste and I really liked it with two cans. I WILL be making this dish often!  It's a perfect side dish, but can readily suffice for a light main course!

text:
Fantastic! My sons, husband and I all loved this recipe.  I made it for the first time tonight and it was great. I followed the recipe with the exception of two things, 1) I reduced the overall cooking time by 5 minutes - I added the corn after 15 minutes, rather than 20, because the liquid seemed to be nearly gone by that point, and 2) I added a can of diced tomatoes and the end with the black beans.  My kids agreed I should make this again tomorrow - so needless to say, this will be new regular.

text:
This was amazing!  I was out of cumin and used taco seasoning instead.  It turned out just fine!  The only suggestion I would give, is that if you plan to reheat this for the next day, to hold the cilantro on the side until you are ready to serve.  (as in...don't "cook" it in initially.  We ate the leftovers anyway, but it would have been better if we had added cilantro separately.  This was also a bit spicy for my 8 year old, so next time I will cut the cayenne in half.

OMG sooooooooo good!!!!  This is my second time eating Quinoa and the 1st time was a disaster.  Since this had such raving reviews decided to give it a go. SUPER good!!!!  I hope my toddler and my hubby will like it too.  If not, oh well more for me :D

text:
This is so good! Using advice from others, I rinsed the quinoa and let it soak for ten minutes.  I used one can of black beans and added half of a red bell pepper.  I waited for it to cool a bit before I added the cilantro so it wouldn't wilt.  I also used vegetable broth and felt it had more than enough flavor.  The colors were beautiful and the spices perfect. It's good both warm and cold. I will make this again and look forward to different variations perhaps adding halved cherry tomatoes or sun-dried tomatoes!  Lot's of options!

text:
This is my favorite recipe! I actually now use this recipe as a base when I am making a quinoa dish. I usually modify it due to personal preferences. I add 1/4 of jalapeno diced and 1/2 to a whole red pepper diced to the onion and garlic as well. I remove the corn for dietary reasons and add fire roasted green chiles when I add the black beans. Everyone I have made this for raves about it!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4526075.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
YUM, I'm so happy to have found this recipe!  I bought a big bag of quinoa from Costco and have been looking for delicious ways to use it up!  I agree with the other reviewers who say that 2 cans of black beans is overkill.  Unless you want beans to be the main ingredient in this dish, definitely stick with just one can so you get a perfect balance of the quinoa, beans and corn.  I also used chicken broth because I don't ever have vegetable broth on hand and I subbed paprika instead of the cayenne since my kids can detect even the slightest amount of heat!  As a result, even my two picky eaters loved this recipe, it made a great and filling lunch for us.  I'm looking forward to the leftovers!

text:
This was my first time making quinoa and this recipe was so easy and so good! I am not a fan of cilantro, so I left that out. Also only added one can of beans as others have said. Two would be way too much. If you are on the fence about trying this recipe, I strongly suggest you try it! I got the quinoa in a box and I didn't have to rinse or soak it, and it turned out perfect each time I have made this by following the recipe's directions. Not bitter at all. Hubby & picky kids even ate it! Tastes good cold too!

text:
This was good - nothing exceptional, but a tasty enough dish.  I added the spices to the sauteed onions and garlic to bring out their flavor, and used homemade chicken stock.  I also adjusted cooking time according to the quinoa I bought.  I will probably make a version of this again, adding more spices and/or other veggies, such as green chiles, to the mix. I do not think 2 cans of beans were too much, as others did. Overall, a good recipe, and a very filling, healthy dish.

text:
My family loved it. It's very tasty, if not terribly interesting, and the inclusion of the cayenne definitely makes the dish. I, too, added only one can of black beans, and that seemed to be just the right amount. I also didn't use cilantro (having none on hand--this is an excellent  "Augh, I have no fresh veggies" emergency dish), and it didn't seem to need it.

ETA: also, this made more like 5 servings (as a main dish) than 10.

text:
The first time I ever tasted quinoa was a couple of years ago and it was not seasoned. It was so awful I swore off it immediately. I thought it looked like cooked birdseeds! 

  Well, today I was feeling the need to cook something healthy and this is the recipe i tried.  I did not have the corn, and instead of 2 cans of black beans I added one of black beans and one of pinto beans.  OMG! This is so delicious.  I wish my husband was home from work so we could eat dinner NOW.  Someone else thought it was bland, but I'm not sure how they could think that. All taste buds are not created equally, obviously!  To me, this is amazing.  I know my hubby will love it as well.

text:
I love this recipe almost as much as I love potato chips!  I substituted 3 cups of dry black beans. I soaked them overnight, then cooked them for about  1 ½ hours before adding them to the recipe (I may have lost some vitamins by cooking them so long – I need to research black bean cooking). I also added a fresh half cup of cilantro right before serving. I love cilantro and it added some nice color and spark to the dish. The next time, I might add a bit of avocado to top it off.

text:
Even my husband liked it and he hates quinoa. (He would've given it 3 stars.) My daughter wanted seconds and my son started eating it with his hands so he could get more in his mouth. I halved the entire recipe to make 5 servings. I doubled the quinoa  and used double chicken broth and I used one can black beans and one can corn. Next time I will triple the the quinoa or add less beans and corn because I personally like a lot of quinoa. The other reviewers are right, there's more than enough black beans. I left out the cayenne pepper but added more black pepper.

text:
Loved this recipe!  I doubled it and did make some changes that pleased my New Mexican Family's taste...I doubled the cumin and instead of Cheyenne pepper, I added 2 Tbs. of red chili spice, 1 red bell pepper, 1 Tbs. of chili lime spice, 4 diced green chili peppers (2 with seeds and veins), and substituted chix broth for veggie broth.  I also halved the amount of black beans, as I didn't want it to overwhelm the dish.  I served this to my family as a "no meat" main dish, and THEY LOVED IT!  I am attempting to change their diets without a lot of whining and this meal is definitely going to help me to do that.  I don't think there is any veggie that you couldn't add to this dish to improve it!

text:
I found that this recipe was a little bland.  I made it again, and ended up adding double garlic and onion, and sauteeing the onions, garlic, cumin,and cayenne together until the aromas were quite strong...maybe 3-5 minutes or so on low heat...

Also, made a difference if you cooked the onions muuch longer on a very low heat so they were quite sweet and caramalized...

To make it a little healthier - I finely chopped kale and added it at the last minute with the corn... and it also made the flavours a little heartier - almost a "nutty" taste...

text:
I'd never had quinoa before and didn't know what to expect at all; I also don't really trust myself to properly prepare things with which I only have passing familiarity. I was pleasantly surprised, as it turns out: this was awesome! I know the recipe doesn't call for any particular type of frozen corn, but I used white and am really glad that I did. (Incidentally, now that I think about it, it's the same story for the onion: white onion = a good choice.) I halved the recipe and ended up using a whole can of beans, which I didn't think was too much...but then, I'm a pretty big fan of black beans. The only other place I deviated from the recipe was in adding avocado and grape tomatoes after cooking; getting a bite with a little bit of everything (quinoa, onion, corn, beans, cilantro, avocado, and tomato, all together) was pretty perfect.

I first tried this recipe a couple of years back and have made it several times. It is now one of my go-to recipes for several reasons: 1. Versatility.  I have cooked this with and without broth, with and without cilantro and cayenne and have added ground turkey several times to make it a main dish.  It is fantastic any way you do it. 2. This is a pantry meal.  I generally have everything on hand to make this delicious, nutritious option. 3. It is fast and easy.  Both the hubs and I work full time and having this recipe in my arsenal has made for several tasty dinners after a long day at work. I can't say enough good about this one.. eat it.  You will love it!

This tastes good cold or hot, tastes even better a few days after it's made, and freezes well.  It's one of my go to healthy weeknight recipes.

text:
Super yum!!  You can buy quinoa at Trader Joes (it comes in red, multi-color, and white).  I used the white quinoa.  I cooked the quinoa in a rice cooker in vegetable broth PRIOR to starting the recipe.  Then, I sauteed the onions and garlic.  Then, threw in the quinoa, stirred in cumin and some oregano, and black beans and corn.  2 cans WAS a bit too much, but I thought 1 can wasn't enough.  So maybe 1 1/2 cans?  It was really really delicious - my hubby, picky 4 year old, AND baby all ate this complete protein-packed meal.  (Mom heaven!)  I cooked this with the Salsa Chicken recipe on this site (in a crockpot).  Also, served with soft avocados.  what a wonderful meal.  Thank yoU!!

My first quinoa recipe EVER, and what a fantastic introduction!! My only changes were cooking the grain in plain water, and I substituted fresh roasted sweet corn off the cob for frozen. I also finished the dish off with a squeeze of fresh lime to add brightness. Totally making again!!!!!

text:
This was excellent!!  So easy and so yummy.  Like others, I omitted one can of black beans and just upped the amount of corn.  I used this as a side dish to Chipotle Marinated chicken skewers with veggies and it was perfect.  If I was using this as a main dish, I would definitely keep the 2nd can of black beans for the protein.  I also omitted the cayenne since I was serving this to my kids.  Instead I used about a teaspoon of Chili powder.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4347898.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I normally try to make every recipe as stated the first time THEN modify, but I'd already started when I realized I didn't have it all.  My imagination is good enough to know I would've still rated this 5 stars, because my variations = 6!!

Here are some things I had to do that might be tips if you find yourself in a similar bind (some due to suggestions of other reviewers - thank you!).

I did not have vegetable broth (though I'd thought I did).  I didn't do chicken broth & tomato juice from canned tomatoes, I did do chicken broth with black bean and corn salsa.  I also upped the quantity of liquid to what the quinoa box said (vs the recipe).  

I added lime juice because it seems like a sin to use cumin without it, also added adobo and chipotle.  I only had Red Inca Quinoa.

I also only had freeze dried garlic and red onion, so I used a hefty one.

I didn't have enough black beans so used a can of chick peas.  Hubby liked them - I wish I had used less because, and I can't believe I'm saying this, the quinoa itself was the star.  1 can of black beans was probably okay, the corn was great (I LOVED having added salsa and even added more - gave great depth) but I started to get mad at the chick peas for getting between me and this delicious, delicious quinoa.

Last time I made quinoa we HATED it, and we're both health nuts and decent cooks, so we didn't have high hopes.  

This.  Was.  Awesome.

Trust it!

It's going to be a new staple in our house! SO good, cheap, and healthy!

text:
This recipe was sooo good!  I was hesitant to try it fearing my expensive quinoa would end up as chicken feed but it was great.  The only change I had to make was substituting canned corn for frozen and I found that I really liked the tender sweetness of the canned corn.  Cilantro is a strong flavored herb that people either love or hate so add with caution.  That being said, since it also turns brown quickly, instead of adding it to the dish I just spinkled it on individual servings to taste so that leftovers wouldn't have slimy brown leaves the next day.  I will definately make this again!

text:
This was a very simple and very delicious recipe. Like some other reviewers, I used olive oil instead of vegetable oil (it's really only to saute the onions and garlic so either will work), added a red bell pepper with the corn for a little extra sweetness and crunch, increased the amount of cayenne pepper (i like my food spicy) and only used one can of black beans. For my first experience cooking with quinoa, I'd say this was a success! Thanks for the recipe.

text:
Oh My G-d!  This is my first time making quinoa and I was a bit nervous.  I took comfort that the flavor profile is one that I love and that there were so many great reviews.  Nothing could have prepared me, though for how great this is!   I used quinoa beads from Trader Joe's and didn't rinse or soak them. Just tossed them in  with a little more onions and garlic than called for.  I also upped the cilantro a tad because I chopped a little too much.  I added the beans I had on hand, 1 can of black and 1/2 can of white with a cup of canned corn. It seemed like it needed just a bit of color so I also chopped some red, yellow and orange mini sweet peppers. Delish!  We will be adding this to our regular recipe rotation!

None
text:
AMAZING! I've never cooked quinoa before, but now I'm sold. My changes: 4 cloves of garlic and chicken broth (UPDATE: 2nd time I used slightly less than 1.5 cups, and it was less liquidy; UPDATE2: 3rd time I used 1 cup of quinoa and 1 can of 14.5oz chicken broth... that is the PERFECT PROPORTION!), no corn, 1 can black beans, 1/2 bunch cilantro chopped (stems and leaves). I made sure to rinse quinoa well before cooking. Simmer covered for 20 minutes, then uncover and cook for 5 minutes (whether or not you add the corn - I don't). The quinoa should be slightly moist when done/there should still be a hint of broth at the bottom of the pan.

This was my first time using quinoa, and it turned out perfectly. The recipe was simple and straightforward. The ingredients were cheap and easily available at the grocery store.

I made this as-is except a few tweaks because of what I had on hand: olive oil instead of vegetable oil chicken broth instead of vegetable broth  I also used 1/2tsp cayenne pepper, omitted the corn because of personal preference, and only used one can of beans because of user comments. I will definitely make again, but next time with only 1/4c cilantro, and maybe more of the chopped onion.

I thought this dish was just "ok".  Kinda bland for my taste.  I have never eaten Quinoa before so maybe I just didn't know what to expect.  My 3 year old son loved it!!  I made it with chicken broth instead of veggie broth, only one can of black beans, leftover roasted chicken cubed and I doubled the cayenne pepper.  This recipe however has great potential!  I plan to make it again, but add more spices and more veggies.   I will double the spices and add a can of tomatoes with jalapenos undrained, red bell pepper and I thought it needed more cilantro. My husband and I love spicy spicy food so I will definitly kick it up a few more notches, maybe add some red pepper flakes.

Excellent recipe, though I agree with a lot of other reviewers in that it needs a bit of tweaking.  I followed the advice of others and doubled the spices.  I like it on the spicier side, so after trying it a couple times, I tried adding in a teaspoon of chipotle/adobo sauce which lended some smokiness to the flavor. text:
Very tasty and simple to make. I used chicken broth, added some red bell pepper, and went light on the cilantro. I also only used one can of beans. And I wouldn't say this is anywhere near "10 servings" if you're using it as your main dish. The backburn you get from the cayenne is really what made this dish. Great served with fresh, cooled avacado slices!

text:
This was GREAT!!  I had to sub chicken broth as many others did.  I think one key is to follow the instructions of your box of quinoa for cooking time.  My quinoa cooked in 8-10 minutes, so had I cooked for 20, it would have been a mushy mess!  I topped mine with some Mexican chicken (breast boiled with bay leaves, oregano, garlic, onion), chopped tomatoes, avocado, and sour cream!  YUMMY!!!  Would definitely be great in a tortilla, too!

My first time making quinoa and it was absolutely delicious!!! However, I substituted chicken stock for vegetable broth and tripled the amount listed in the recipe. By tripling the broth, my quinoa was much more tender, and the chicken stock gave it a wonderful flavor, although I'm sure vegetable broth would be just as tasty! Five stars for quinoa AND for this delicious recipe!

text:
This was the first time I ever cooked quinoa. I like how simple and tasty this recipe is. I also chopped up some red pepper as others had suggested and cooked it with the garlic and onions.  With the seasonings I added some chilli powder and extra cumin and cayenne. I used canned kernel corn and added it at the end, along with some green onion. I only used one can of black beans too. I didn't add any cilantro though. I love it but others don't like it at all, so I didn't try it. It was enjoyed by all.  I especially like the subtle nutty flavour of the quinoa. I am going to be cooking with it a lot more now. Thanks for the recipe :)

This is my favorite quinoa recipe.  I use frozen roasted corn kernels and 1 can black beans.  The 2nd can of beans probably makes for a heartier meal, but my family isn't that keen on black beans to begin with so I don't push my luck.    We love this vegetarian, but as an alternative, you can add precooked sliced chicken apple sausages or smoked sausage at the end for a heartier 1 dish meal.

text:
If you have never made Quinoa & are a little hesitant to try it....try this recipe! I have never made Quinoa (or even tasted it) prior to making this recipe. I have been seeing Quinoa in a lot more recipes lately so I decided to give it a go. I added a 1/2t more cumin as recommended. I also diced up a tomato & added it right before serving. It added a nice pop of color. This recipe is delicious cold or warm. It also makes A LOT so you will be lucky enough to have leftovers. I added shredded chicken to it the following day & turned it into a burrito filling for lunch the next day & it was a great hearty addition! I can't wait to make more! This recipe definitely earns the 5 stars.

iluvcats

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677173.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We thought this was just excellent.  I did add a can of Rotel tomatoes with chiles (this will kick the heat up a bit more), and we squeezed lime juice on it before eating.  A very healthy, tasty dish, economical, and it's going in the regular rotation.  Just a note if you're unfamiliar with quinoa - be sure to RINSE THE QUINOA WITH WATER before putting it in the pot. Quinoa has a natural substance on it that acts as a repellant to birds and such, and it has a bitter taste to it. While it won't hurt you, it will adversely affect the flavor of the dish.  Rinsing with water before you cook it removes this substance. While some brands may be pre-rinsed, others, like the brand we can get, are not.

I recovered it and it came out well.  It needs twice as much liquid as suggested. I cooked it carefully, and added water as needed--about two more cups. I used one can of black beans in order to appreciate the quinoa and cilantro more fully. Found plenty of quinoa locally at Whole Foods, in bulk, at $3.76/lb.  My Mexican friend, especially, was surprised and pleased with it and gave it a full two thumbs up!!  I repeated it a second evening. Will offer it frequently.

text:
Very tasty. I added a red bell pepper and subbed chicken stock for the veggie stock, and served with sour cream and avocado. This made up our entire meal, so for us it made 4 meal-sized servings, not 10 side dish-sized servings. Will definitely make again, but might up the spices a bit - good blend of flavors, just not enough. I got quinoa in the bulk section of our local supermarket for $3.99/lb, and I needed less than 1/2 a pound, so it was very economical for us. Also, I only soaked the quinoa for about 3 minutes (just while I was getting the chicken stock ready), and it was perfectly cooked according to the recipe's directions - if I'd soaked it for an hour I would have had slop for dinner!

I usually do my quinoa with a tomato/garbanzo bean mixture, but this was dang good.  And, as usual with quinoa, it's better cold a day or two later.  I only did one can of black beans.  I also did a cup of quinoa, 2 cups chicken broth and added half a chopped green bell pepper to the onions.  At the end I mixed in some lime juice too - only about a tablespoon.   Next time I make this I think I'll add a tomato and a little more lime juice.   I think it will be perfect then.

This is great.  I had nothing to make for lunch and received the email with the link to quinoa recipes. I remembered I had some quinoa and made this using chicken stock, frozen sweet peas (no corn) I added red pepper, used the cilantro as suggested by another reviewer, instead of black beans I used aduki beans I had just gotten for the first time.  They're even healthier than black beans.  It made for a very yummy lunch and leftovers!  You can't go wrong with quinoa you can mix it with just about anything. Make it a side dish or whole meal.

text:
This was a great base recipe.  I would have given it 5 stars, but I did change/add to the recipe a bit.  I had never made quinoa before, but have been wanting to try it for a while.  I did not rinse or soak the quinoa, as a previous review suggested, but I did add it to the sauteed onions and garlic.  I also added carrots to the onions and garlic (for color and nutrients).  In addition, I added fresh peas when I added the broth and spices.  I also used paprika instead of cayenne as I was feeding my 1 year old (who absolutely loved this.)  I also added some edamame at the end to bump up the protein.  I left out the cilantro because I didn't have any, but think it would have been a great addition.  This was a great meal, and probably would have been awesome as written.

text:
I LOVE this recipe, as does everyone I have made it for, I totally give it 5 stars...However, one word of warning: It has to be eaten quickly. It does not seem to keep for any more then 2 days. One time I made it on a Thursday, took it in to work Friday to share, accidentally left what was not eaten in the fridge at work, walked in Monday morn, the entire HUGE office smelled like a dead body was there, opened the fridge and almost passed out. Made it again this weekend, Friday morning to be exact, and Sunday at noon it was very smelly and made my entire kitchen stink, in sealed bowl in the fridge. Great salad, but must eat the day it's made only, in my opinion. BTW, I have not made much w/ Quinoa, is this a Quinoa thing, is it known not to keep for long?

text:
Fantastic!  I made this in a smaller size, for four.  Based on other reviews, I added in 1 chopped tomato, 2 tbsp green chiles and 1/2tsp smoked paprika.  I didn't have cilantro so I substituted oregano.  The one thing I'd mention, which might be because I made a smaller serving, is the quinoa is sticky when wet so it's hard to mix in the seasonings after - next time I'll add them to the broth beforehand.  This dish is amazing!!!

I didn't change anything about the recipe, except for use one can of black beans and one can of white kidney beans, because I didn't have two cans of black beans. But regardless, this has excellent flavor and the combination of textures is perfect! Thanks for submitting this!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I think this recipe is tops!  I made it almost as is, I replaced the 1 cup of corn with diced yellow and red bell peppers and increased the cayanne pepper to 1/2 tsp and added an extra 1/2 tsp of cumin. Also, like many of the other reviewers I only used 1 can of black beans and I'm glad I did.  The consistancy is just right.   At this point I am kinda obsessed with this recipe.  It is a satisfying and tasty, HEALTHY meal that doesn't *taste* healthy.  So far I've only had it wrapped in a tortilla with hot sauce but I plan on making enchilada's with it next week.  PS~ If you're using canned broth, don't be tempted to use the whole can or your dish will be kinda soupy.  Only use the 1 1/2 cups called for.  Thank you SO much for the recipe!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674163.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my first time trying Quinoa and I am so happy that I used this recipe; it was simply delicious. I did have to make some changes based on what I had on hand. I only used 1 can of black beans (19 oz can), and as others have noted, I do think 30 ounces would have been too much; substituted the veggie broth for low-fat/low sodium chicken broth; and used 1/4 tsp chili powder instead of the cayenne. I also did not add cilantro because I don't really care for it. Last, I ended up adding some leftover chicken, which I needed to use up. I will definitely be making this again. It is a nice and hearty protein-packed dish, yet it does not feel heavy. I went back for seconds, and am trying to resist thirds. This is definitely a keeper!
Review:

This recipe is sooo easy to make and sooo delicious!!!  The second time I made it I did make a few adjustments to give it a little bit more pop.  

I about doubled the cayenne pepper
I sauteed red/yellow/orange bell peppers with the onions.  
I did about 2/3 of the beans.

But as a base recipe this was delicious, and I will make plenty of variations of it in the future.  I imagine you could add meat to it and make it the main dish....mmmm!!

This was my first experience with quinoa and it certainly won't be my last.  This is an excellent recipe that is also easy to add to (as I love to do!).  I used one can of beans, the Rotel tomatoes and julienne zucchini as per others' suggestions...delish! All in all, a HUGE success. My husband adored it!

I am just learning to cook with quinoa and I thought that this recipe really looked good.  I used one can of beans and one can of drained corn.  I thought it was a little bland.  For my meat dish I was making "my kids favorite pork chops" (a recipe I got from this site)and so I took some of the juice (BBQ sauce and beer) from that pan and added to the quinoa.  I thought it was pretty tasty and hubby didn't think it was that bad.  He said it needed some rice in it for texture so I might try it again.  None of the stores by me sell quinoa so I called Bob's Red Mill company and ordered it (you don't have to rinse theirs).  I think this is a good base recipe that can be tweeked to your particuliar taste.

text:
Delicious! I changed it a lot, but still a great starting point. I halved the recipe but used 1/2 cup quinoa and 1 cup chicken broth. I didn't have garlic or cayenne so I used about 1/2 t Emeril's Essence and a dash of red pepper flakes. I steamed 3 diced carrots and added at the end with the corn. I also added cut up vegetarian chicken nuggets and mixed them in my portion for more protein. Amazing, well-rounded meal!

I had never heard of Quinoa till this week. I did a search on the Web for a recipe to use it and found this recipe. I can't believe it - it is FANTASTIC and I can't wait to make it again. I added a chopped carrot with the onion and garlic and used chicken broth. Otherwise I made it exactly as written and won't be doing any more substitutions. I can't wait to try it as an omelet filling as someone suggested.

text:
I use quinoa often and found this to be a delicious and versatile addition to my recipe book.  The proportions of quinoa/corn/beans are perfect.  I made this in August and used 1 ear of fresh corn, also had some finely chopped celery and green pepper around, so tossed those in, and used parsley instead of cilantro.  I also browned the quinoa before adding the liquid.  It made a great main dish, good for wraps and scoops, and will try using wine for some of the liquid next time.
